prog_name: ALGAL FOREST RESTORATION IN MEDITERRANEAN SEA
funder_moreinfo: This project has received funding from the European Union’s EMFF programme under grant agreement – EASME/EMFF/2017/1.2.1.12/S4/01/SI2.789059.
key_inst: POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF MARCHE,  Stazione Zoologica Napoli,  UNIVERSITE’ NICE SOPHIA ANTIPOLIS,  UNIVERSITAT DE GIRONA, Hellenic Center for Marine Research,  HELLENIC AGRICULTURAL ORGANIZATION-DEMETER, UN ENVIRONMENT WORLD CONSERVATION MONITORING CENTRE, ECOREACH, UNIVERSITY OF VLORA “ISMAIL QEMALI”,  FACULTY OF SCIENCES OF BIZERTE, UNIVERSITY OF CARTHAGE,  UNIVERSITY CHOUAIB DOUKKALI
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: Recently, the EU funded the MERCES (http://www.merces-project.eu/) project which seeks to revise current concepts and understanding relating to the restoration, recovery and human-mediated modification of coastal and marine ecosystems. The project has pushed forward current knowledge of marine restoration techniques and is producing novel and critical information relating to best practices across different habitats, including Cystoseira. Similarly, the Life ROC-POP (Promoting biodiversity enhancement by Restoration Of Cystoseira POPulations, LIFE16 NA T/IT/000816) project is seeking to reintroduce two Cystoseira spp. within protected sites (e.g. MPAs, Natura 2000 sites, etc.). Here, capitalising on the experience gained and the knowledge accumulated in these and other projects, we have formulated a consortium that will improve existing, and develop new restoration techniques to efficiently restore degraded macroalgal forests (AFRIMED interactions with MERCES and Life ROC-POP projects).
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: The idea is that capitalising on the experience gained and the knowledge accumulated in these and other projects, we have formulated a consortium that will improve existing, and develop new restoration techniques to efficiently restore degraded macroalgal forests
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: We studied the cover of seven perennial (C. amentacea, C. barbata, C. barbatula, C. corniculata, C. crinita, C. foeniculacea, and C. mediterranean) and one semi-perennial (C. compressa) Cystoseira species at three spatial scales (location, meadow, transect) from four (4) countries and eight (8) different locations across the Mediterranean Sea (Greece: 2; Albania: 1; Italy: 2; Morocco: 3). In formation about anthropogenic stressors (urbanization, agriculture, mariculture, sewage, harbor) are also included in the project
duration_moreinfo: THe project will finish next year (2021). However, the intention is to continue sampling
protocols_moreinfo: Two spatial scales (location, site) with three to twelve (n=3-12) metallic or plastic quadrates each site

dataaccess_restriction_level: Fully restricted access- only data provider/program/network has access
data_aggregators_list: We are trying to create a data portal with data collected from this project and from a systematic literature assessment. The response variable collected  is always cover.

type_moreinfo: ALTER-Net brings together leading institutes from 18 European countries. They share the goal of integrating their research capability to: assess changes in biodiversity, analyse the effect of those changes on ecosystem services and inform the public and policy makers about this at a European scale. Originally funded by the European Union’s Framework VI program to stimulate a collaborative approach, ALTER-Net is now operating independently. Since 2009 ALTER-Net's budget has been supported through financial pledges and in-kind contributions from our partners across Europe.

funder_moreinfo: ACCESS is a private/public partnership founded by Point Blue Conservation Science, NOAA's Cordell Bank National Marine Sanctuary, and NOAA's Greater Farallones National Marine Sanctuary.
key_inst: NOAA's Cordell Bank National Marine Sanctuary, NOAA's Greater Farallones National Marine Sanctuary.
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_moreinfo: ACCESS members jointly conduct integrated, collaborative, and multi-disciplinary research to monitor the distribution and abundance of marine wildlife in the context of underlying physical and biological oceanographic processes.  Our research inform managers, policy-makers and conservation partners about wildlife responses to changes in ocean conditions and human threats in order to mobilize public support for marine conservation.  The main research topics and management issues we aim to address include:  1) Saving whales from ship strikes – recommend management approaches that will save whales off San Francisco,  2) Reducing whale entanglements – identify high entanglement-risk areas to decrease bycatch in crab fisheries,  3) Protecting wildlife hotspots – protect wildlife and decrease conflicts with existing and proposed new human uses,  4) Developing ecosystem indicators – track ecosystem responses to climate change and inform climate-smart conservation, and  5) Tracking ocean acidification – document changes in water chemistry and assess biological responses.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Graduate students, Teacher-At-Sea, field and lab interns

freq_moreinfo: We conduct 3-4 cruises per year, sampling spring (May/June), summer (July) and fall seasons (September)

freq_moreinfo: At least all the five sites are sampling two times a year, but one of them (Islas Marietas National park) has a bimonthly sampling schedule since 2009 to present.
protocols_moreinfo: We have a standard protocol for sampling in coral reef areas, five 25m transects per site where we collect data for live coral cover (six 1 square meter frame along transect), reef fish visual census 25x4m (100 sqm area), and visual census of invertebrates (equinoderms and some other of economic importance).

type_moreinfo: Since 1990, the Bedford Institute of Oceanography (BIO) has been conducting annual occupation (May) of an oceanographic section across the Labrador Sea, following the World Ocean Circulation Experiment (WOCE) array known as the AR7W (Atlantic Repeat 7-West) hydrography line. These surveys cover a wide range of physical, chemical biological characteristics and properties of seawater, e.g., temperature, salinity, density, currents, dissolved oxygen, nutrients, chlorofluorocarbons, sulfur hexafluoride, total inorganic carbon, pH, oxygen, iodine isotopes, particulate organic carbone (POC), Pigments composition and abundacne (HPLC), bacteria until 2012, phytoplankton and mesozooplankton abundance and diversity.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Program is often use as a platform to develop and test new technologies in the field.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
freq_moreinfo: Occuation of the AR7W line happens typically in May, essentially in order to sample around the phytoplanktpon bloom formation throughout the Labrador Sea and also to obtain an accurate measurement of the winter deep convection, a key physical phenomenon within the region.     Ocean color, also part of our monitoring procedure, with daily coverage.
protocols_moreinfo: Protocoles are following Mitchell, M.R., Harrison, G., Pauley, K., Gagné, A., Maillet, G., and Stain, P. 2002. Atlantic zonal monitoring program sampling protocol. Can. Tech. Rep. Hydrogr. Ocean Sci. no. 223. iv + 23.

vars_moreinfo: Look - we're not an observing network, so some of these questions don't really seem relevant, but you've sent me a couple of emails insistently asking me to complete this survey, so hopefully this is of some use.  We archive and catalogue data, we don't collect it (the scientists in our Antarctic program collect the data, but it's mostly on an ad hoc basis.  There are some longer term projects, but as with everything, they come and go).
MM_vars_age: Age (year, age class, life history stage)
MM_protocol_other: Once again - we archive the data, not collect it.  I'm sure that the collecting scientists have standards that they follow when collecting in order to verify the veracity of the science, but that's their responsibility, not the responsibility of the data centre.
AnythingElse: I'm really not sure that this survey is appropriate for data centres (or at least not our data centre), which is why I didn't complete it when you sent me the first email, I just forwarded it onto other people.

spatial_moreinfo: The CPR is towed behind a vessel so has a large spatial and temporal coverage. The survey aims to use vessels that have consistent tracks so that routes are repeated seasonally which will result in times series style data over time.
protocols_moreinfo: The CPR surveys around the world collect data in exactly the same way. There are some differences however in how the samples are analysed.   Much of the methodology for AusCPR is described in Richardson et al 2006, http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.553.284&rep=rep1&type=pdf  The zooplankton analysis for AusCPR is described here  https://catalogue-imos.aodn.org.au/geonetwork/srv/eng/metadata.show?uuid=c1344e70-480e-0993-e044-00144f7bc0f4  Best practice is described here: https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmars.2019.00321/full

vars_moreinfo: For each sample a category of 'greenness' is assigned. This is a measure of the chlorophyll called the phytoplankton colour index. See Richardson et al 2006, link previously supplied for details.
AnythingElse: There is a global network of CPR surveys called the Global Alliance of CPR surveys, (GACS). One of the aims of GACS is to provide a standardised data set of all CPR survey data and make this freely available by creating an OBIS CPR node. This is due to be completed shortly.  see https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmars.2019.00321/full for details.

prog_abbrev: Individual series are identifed and enompass ocean biological moorings, annual acoustic survey of Antarctic krill and asscoiated oceanographic measurements and monitoring of seabird and marine mammal breeding performance at 2 sites in the Scotia Sea.
prog_network: see individual project links - includes Commission for Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources  CCAMLR monitoring programme; the ocean moorings project contributes data  to the UNESCO/IOC International Ocean Carbon Coordination Project (IOCCP)
prog_funders: Natural Environment Research Council, (NERC, UKRI), UK
type_moreinfo: We have a range of long term observation projects corodinated by the BAS Ecosystems Team.      These include:  1. Ocean mooring systems in the northern Scotia Sea (Southern Ocean) for the collection of biological oceanographic data.  These are multi-instrument sensor systems, including sediment traps and other instrumentation for examing ocean carbon budgets and pH; physical sensor for ocean temperature and salinity; bioacoustic systems for deriving estimates of backscatter for estimation of zooplankton (incl. krill) and fish densities and distribution; passive acoustic systems for study of marine mammals.          2.  An annual bioacoustic and net survey of krill dsitribution and biomass near South Georgia in the Scotia Sea.  This provides an annual estimate of local krill biomass. A range of supporting physical and biological oceanographic measurements are also collected during teh survey.      3.  Year round monitoring of predator numbers and annual assessments of breeding success of seabird (penguins, albatross speceis) and marine mammals (fur seals) at Bird Island, Soyuth Georgia.  Annual assessments of numbers and breeding sucess of penguins are also undertaken at Signy Island, South Orkney Islands, Scotia Sea.      See individual project website links for details.  BAS Polar Data centre.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: Each of series have different start dates dependent on data type and purpose.  See individual datasets for details.
freq_moreinfo: Each of the datasets is different.  Some are once annually some are within year.  Individual instruments have specific recording frequencies.
protocols_moreinfo: Note spatial markers are approximate - individual data sets provide more detail on location/spatial extent.  Please check those for details.

type_moreinfo: Basismonitoring Wadden monitors the developments in the Dutch Waddensea region. Because managers of the Dutch Waddensea region share collected data and knowledge with each other, monitoring can be done more effectively and efficiently. The datahouse Wadden, part of Basismonitoring Wadden, provides virtual access to the best available information about the Dutch Waddensea area. It provides the monitoring agenda, the maps- and data- portal and will act as a gathering place for investigations in the Dutch Waddensea area.

prog_funders: Greater Farallones National Marine Sanctuary, Resources Legacy Foundation, Firedoll Foundation, Golden Gate National ParksConservancy, Sidney Stern Memorial Trust, Bernice Barbour Foundation, Tanklage Foundation
key_inst: MPA Watch, California Academy of Science Marine Mammal Stranding Network,
type_moreinfo: Beach Watch is a public private partnership between Greater Farallones National Marine Sanctuary (GFNMS) and Greater Farallones Association. This bi-monthly coastal monitoring program provides abundance and trends of live and dead birds and mammals, human uses, oil deposition, wrack abundance and status of stream openings. Beach Watch has conducted bi-monthly surveys of central California beaches since 1994.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: The program started sampling in it's current form in 1993. Prior to 1993 there is at least ten years of beach cast bird data at some of these locations. In 2014 all survey sites north of Bodega bay were initiated.
freq_moreinfo: Surveys are completed two times per month 24x per year at each site.
protocols_moreinfo: Survey and Quality Assurance Protocols are available upon request.

prog_network: The BBMP is managed by the Atlantic Zone Monitoring Program (AZMP)
prog_funders: Fisheries and Oceans Canada
key_inst: Dalhousie University, Nova Scotia Community Collage
type_moreinfo: Please refer to the website for more information or contact me directly (Andrew.Cogswell@dfo-mpo.gc.ca).
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: We work closely with the local University and Community Collage. While it is not our mandate to assist with capacity or technology transfer, our program, platform and staff often facilitate the deployment of developing technology.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: The exact sampling location for the BBMP can be found here: http://www.bio.gc.ca/science/monitoring-monitorage/bbmp-pobb/description-en.php
duration_moreinfo: The program has been sampling some varialbes since 1992, but regular standardized weekly sampling began in 1999.
freq_moreinfo: Sampling happens weekly, usually on a wednesday.
protocols_moreinfo: Mitchell, M.R., G. Harrison, K. Pauley, A. Gagné, G. Maillet, and P. Strain. 2002. Atlantic Zonal Monitoring Program Sampling Protocol. Can. Tech. Rep. Hydrogr. Ocean Sci. 223: iv + 23 pp.

dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask

vars_moreinfo: The parameters sampled weekly are described here:    http://www.bio.gc.ca/science/monitoring-monitorage/bbmp-pobb/measurements-mesures-en.php
AnythingElse: The Atlantic Zone Off-Shelf Monitoring Program is another sister program currently managed by Mr. Marc Ringuette (Marc.Ringuette@dfo-mpo.gc.ca)

prog_name: Belgian Offshore Wind Farm Environmental Monitoring Programme
prog_funders: the WinMon.BE is a federal state funded program
funder_moreinfo: Monitoring of the impacts of offshore wind farms in the Belgian part of the North Sea is mandatory and is a part of the environmental permit of the wind farm developers. The developers contribute to a common pot that covers the costs of the monitoring program. The coordination of the program and research strategy is the responsibility of the federal state (i.c. RBINS).
key_inst: Research Institute Nature and Forest (INBO), Research Institute for Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (ILVO), Marine Biology research Group of Ghent University
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: many master thesis students and PhD students are involved in the program
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: all sampling takes places in the Belgian part of the North Sea. Most of the sampling is focused on the offshore wind farms and reference areas, but because of the multitude of studies (e.g. multibeam, benthic sampling, seabird surveys, passive acoustic monitoring of marine mammals) it is not possible to have all sampling location in one .csv. If you have more questions regarding the sampling locations you can contact me.
freq_moreinfo: this is irregular: sampling campaigns for benthos, epibenthos, fish are several times per year; seabird surveys are monthly; monitoring of birds (radar), bats (bat detectors) and marine mammals (PAM) are continuously

funder_moreinfo: The BATS program is funded by the U.S. National Science Foundation through a competitive grant submission process.
key_inst: University of California San Diego, University of Illinois, Old Dominion University, Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory/Columbia University, Skidaway Institute of Ocean Sciences, University of Washington, Oregon State University, National Oceanography Center at Southampton (UK), University of Oxford, University of California Santa Cruz, University of Puerto Rico, University of Chicago, Ohio State University, Monterrey Bay Aquarium and Research Institute
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: The BATS program is a very broadly defined biogeochemical time-series, making a wide range of measurements in biological, chemical and physicals fields.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: The BATS program is a US research asset and therefore we support the efforts of external users for participation on cruises.  In some instances, those external users are developing capacity and/or technology transfer.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: Different biological variables have different start dates, but the earliest were with the beginning of the time-series in October 1988.
freq_moreinfo: During the ~3month winter/spring transition period sampling is biweekly.

prog_name: Biodiversity, extreme environment and global change
prog_funders: Université Pierre and Marie Curie, Fondation Total,
funder_sector_other: Partnershio between academia, research institution, private foundation and government (MPA), Parc Naturel Marin du Golf du Lion
funder_moreinfo: The monitoring programme was developped under the frame of a Research and Training Chair (2010-2018). Funding allowed chartering of a ROV every year for joint surveys, sampling and experiments at two integrated study sites (200 to 600m depth range)
key_inst: Sorbonne University, CNRS, Agence Française de la Biodiversité
type_moreinfo: Monitoring of deep-water coral biocenoses  Yearly sampling of sediments for biogeochemistry and meiofauna  Hydrological parameters
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: 5 to 10 students and post-doc per year have been involved in the programme during their internship and /or through participation to at-sea operations (ROV dives, sediment sampling, cold-water coral and wood fall experiments). Several of them from countries other than France, including countries with no deep-sea research large programmes.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: The two monitored area of this long-term observing programme have been selected for cold-water abundances in the canyon head - based on surveys from the MEDSEACAN submarine canyon exploration programme (2008-2009) - French Agency of Marine Protected Area
duration_moreinfo: Annual ROV surveys interrupted in 2018, sediment sampling continuated in 2019. Future ROV operations planned.
freq_moreinfo: The frequency of ROV surveys will evolve from annual to multiannual
protocols_moreinfo: Best pratices from deep-sea research ecology but no standardize procedure. Methodological development are on-going for surveys
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Limited access- many entities have access to raw data (e.g. something is hindering it being fully open such as a moratorium or a secure login is needed)
dataaccess_moreinfo: The surveys and data series are currently being analyzed for publication. A moratorium is on-going.
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: Support for choosing the best strategy to share the raw data (including videos) will be appreciated
In_OBIS: No; none of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_network: ICES Working Group on Phytoplankton and Microbial Ecology
prog_funders: NSF, Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences
funder_moreinfo: This time-series has been partially funded by a few grants from the National Science Foundation over time.   When not funded, the Facility for Aquatic Cytometry at Bigelow Laboratory has funded this work.
key_inst: ICES WGPME, IGMETS, The Marine Ecological Time Series Database (Metabase Explorer: https://www.st.nmfs.noaa.gov/copepod/time-series/us-10401/)
type_moreinfo: Booth Bay is a small mesotidal embayment located along midcoast Maine in New England, near the town of West Boothbay Harbor, with no direct major river input. Circulation is dominated by strong semi-diurnal tidal mixing with offshore Gulf of Maine coastal waters. The monitoring site was initiated from a floating dock in 2000 located near the State of Maine’s Department of Marine Resources. The purpose of the study is to monitor long-term physical and chemical changes, and phytoplankton population dynamics. Weekly (or bi-weekly) observations at high tide of phytoplankton, bacteria, and eukaryotic heterotrophs are made using flow cytometry. Temperature, salinity (refractometer measurements), and size-fractionated Chlorophyll a (< 3, 3–20, and >20 μm) are also determined. Flow cytometric ataxonomic groups are defined and enumerated (Synechococcus, cryptophytes, and total phytoplankton < 20 μm). Bacteria are detected and enumerated using PicoGreen, a DNA stain (Invitrogen; Veldhuis et al., 1997). Heterotrophic and mixotrophic eukaryotes (microflagellates and small ciliates) are detected using the food vacuole stain Lysotracker Green (Invitrogen; Rose et al., 2004). Microplankton taxonomic distribution (15–300 μm) and abundance are collected using an imaging cytometer, FlowCAM (Sieracki et al., 1998). As of 2012, samples for nutrient analysis are also collected.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: This is a small operation, data is collected, minimal funding for analyzing data and data dissemination.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: This is a single point site (located off a Dock)  Booth Bay, Maine, USA  northwest Atlantic shelf  Latitude:   43.8444     Longitude:   -69.6409
duration_moreinfo: Since 2000 we have attempted to sample on a weekly basis, however, over the past two years - sampling has decreased to twice per month due to lack of staffing.
freq_moreinfo: None of the above (you need a "other" option)  Weekly/bi-monthly
protocols_moreinfo: Protocols have been documented by the Facility for Aquatic Cytometry - and also use referenced sources.    The purpose of the study is to monitor long-term physical and chemical changes, and phytoplankton population dynamics. Weekly observations at high tide of phytoplankton, bacteria, and eukaryotic heterotrophs are made using flow cytometry. Temperature, salinity (refractometer measurements), and size-fractionated Chlorophyll a (< 3, 3–20, and >20 μm) are also determined. Flow cytometric ataxonomic groups are defined and enumerated (Synechococcus, cryptophytes, and total phytoplankton < 20 μm). Bacteria are detected and enumerated using PicoGreen, a DNA stain (Invitrogen; Veldhuis et al., 1997) or SYBRGreen. Heterotrophic and mixotrophic eukaryotes (microflagellates and small ciliates) are detected using the food vacuole stain Lysotracker Green (Invitrogen; Rose et al., 2004). Microplankton taxonomic distribution (15–300 μm) and abundance are collected using an imaging cytometer, FlowCAM (Sieracki et al., 1998). As of 2012, samples for nutrient analysis and zooplankton (vertical net tows) are also collected.

dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: Lack of funding, staff and analysis, also data is stored locally and there are limited locations for deposition of imaging data.

funder_moreinfo: FONACIT is the federal funding agency from Venezuela
key_inst: University of South Carolina, Stony Brook University, Fundacion la Salle de Ciencias Naturales de Venezuela, Universidad de Oriente, Universidad Simon Bolivar, Instituto Venezolano de Investigaciones Cientificas
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: The CARIACO Ocean Time-Series Program operated between 1995 and 2017. It studied the relationship between surface primary production (carbon fixation rates by photosynthesis of planktonic algae), the diversity of the plankton community (phytoplankton, zooplankton, bacteria), regional hydrography, physical forcing variables (such as the wind), and the settling flux of particulate organic carbon in the Cariaco Basin.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Between 1995 and 2017, the CARIACO program trained many technicians, undergraduate students, and masters and doctoral students in the US and in Venezuela. Many people from other locations also visited and trained at the time series station.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: The ocean time series generally focused on collecting monthly observations from the same location (10.5N, 64.66W) in the Cariaco Basin. The Cariaco Basin is a large (∼160 km long, 70 km wide) and deep (∼1,400 m)basin, located on the Venezuelan continental shelf.
freq_moreinfo: Microbial (bacteria) diversity and productivity was measured twice per year, some years more frequently. Sediment flux was estimated every two weeks. There were some interruptions in all of these series.

prog_funders: Alfred P. Sloan Foundation provided the programmatic "glue" funds including develpment of OBIS; research was funded by numerous government and private sources internationally (too numerous to list)
funder_moreinfo: Alfred P. Sloan Foundation (private) provided the administrative glue funding; research was supported through the usual academic proposal process to numerous governments funding agencies and foundations around the world. Note that this program had a ten-year duration and concluded in 2010. Only OBIS (Ocean Biogeographic Information System) endures as a legacy to the Census of Marine Life and serves the data from the program (as well as other data sources).
key_inst: Due to the large number of contributing institutions, I list only the project "hubs": University of Rhode Island, Rutgers University, Scripps Institution of Oceanography, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Australian Institute of Oceanography, Vancouver Aquarium, University of Southern Maine, Fisheries and Oceans Canada, Kyoto University, University of Alaska Fairbanks, Ifremer, Louisiana State University, University of Hawaii, German Centre for Marine Biodiversity Research, University of Connecticut, University of Tokyo, Alfred Wegener Institute for Polar and Marine Research, Stanford University, University of California Santa Cruz, Norwegian Institute of Marine Research, University of Bergen, National Oceanography Centre UK, Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, NIWA, Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research, Australian Antarctic Division, Marine Biological Laboratory, Royal Netherlands Institute for Sea Research, Trinity College Dublin, Roskilde University, University of New Hampshire, Dalhousie University, Memorial University Newfoundland, Duke University, Universidad Simon Bolivar, Scientific Committee on Oceanic Research
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_moreinfo: Provided species (or operational taxonomic unit) level information related to global habitat-based diversity, distribution, and abundance. Habitats covered: coral reefs, intertidal and coastal, pelagic, mesopelagic, abyssal plains, seamounts, chemosynthetic environments, continental margins, Arctic, Antarctic, and regional seas.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Capacity development was not a central focus of the program; however, there was a mandate to provide open access to data and publications, as well as some training mainly in the intertidal zone research
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: I do not have access to csv files and there are more than 10 sampling sites; I will provide a map of locations by email.
freq_moreinfo: The Census of Marine Life had 14 component field programs and each had a different sampling approach and frequency, ranging from daily (through animal telemetry) to once per year expeditions to specific locations.
protocols_moreinfo: Projects developed their own standard protocols, but these were not necessarily formal international standards.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: No, the raw data are publicly accessible/open.
dataaccess_restriction_level: NA
dataaccess_moreinfo: OBIS serves the species occurrence data. Some of the Census projects had other data which may not be served in OBIS. But all of the data in OBIS is fully and publicly accessible.

prog_funders: NOAA, NASA, NOPP, CA OPC
key_inst: https://www.cencoos.org/about/program/membership
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_moreinfo: We have four key Objectives: 1) Observe coastal and ocean physical, biogeochemical, biology and ecosystem variables; 2) Streamline access to information including through a publicly accessible portal; 3) Provide access to improved ocean models and other tools to scale information from individual observations to tools relevant for policy and management; 4) Engage marine stakeholders to create accessible, integrative and valuable information products to inform decision-making and policy. One of the key evolutions in our strategy for 2020-2025 will be to build on our strong foundation in ocean physics and grow capability for observing biogeochemical, biological and ecosystem variables.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: We regularly have CeNCOOS-affiliated projects in the NOAA Ocean Technology Transfer funding stream and others like it. This has included work towards bringing in new tools such as photography (including the Imaging Flow Cytobot), ocean sound sensing and eDNA into a more operational domain.

prog_funders: Citizen Science Programmes, Pelagos Segretariat, Italian Ministry of the Environment
funder_moreinfo: Tethys’ ongoing long term CSR project have been conceived as responsible tourism/citizen science projects. The  contributions  of  the  participants  over the  years  represent  the  main  funding  source  for  the research. Non-specialists are a valuable help for researchers in the field. Participants are involved in all aspects of the fieldwork and of the management of the life on board.
key_inst: CSR collaborate with most of the institutes, NGOs and MPA within the Pelagos  Sanctuary  for  Mediterranean  marine  mammals.
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_Directory: Directory of programs/networks/observatories (the program provides information on observing networks/programs)
type_moreinfo: The Cetacean Sanctuary Research(CSR), established in 1990 is a long-term project of the Tethys Research Institute focusing on the ecology, behavior,  feeding habits and conservation of the cetacean species living in the Pelagos  Sanctuary,  including  fin  whales,  sperm  whales,  striped  dolphins,  long-finned  pilot  whales, and Risso’s dolphins. Cetacean Sanctuary Research   is  conducted  on  board  the research  vessel  “Pelagos”  a  21-meter motorsailer,   that cruises around the Ligurian Sea  between  Italy,  France  and  Corsica  from  May  to  October,  departing  weekly  from  Sanremo,  Italy.  The  Ligurian  Sea  presents  both  a  deep-water  and  a  shelf-slope  habitat,   suitable  for  the  breeding  and  foraging  needs  of  eight  commonly  occurring  cetacean  species.  It  has  one  of  the  highest concentrations of whales and dolphins in the Mediterranean.  The  study  area  covers  about  25,000  km2  between  Genoa,  Porquerolles  islands,  and  Cape  Corse on the island of Corsica.  The summer surveys are conducted from May to September.   Cetaceans' survey is conducted both visually, by dedicated observers and  acoustically,  by using  a  300 m towed  hydrophone array. Once spotted, cetaceans are approached and followed respecting a code of conduct that minimize the disturbance to the animals. Geographic position, group size, group composition and environmental data are always recorded, together with other variables. Every  thirty  minutes,  while  searching  for  cetaceans,  a  “sampling  station”  is  performed  by  recording  navigation  data  (position,  speed,  course),  environmental  data  (sea  state,  weather, visibility)  and  qualitative  acoustic  data  (acoustic  pollution  and  cetacean  vocalizations),  on a dedicated software. Human activities are also monitored (counting the number and type of boats, ships and fishing activities. The presence of other marine animals is also reported: sea turtles, tunas, swordfish, sunfish, giant devil rays (Mediterranean manta rays), other fish schools and  sea  birds  are  often  among  the  various  sea  life  recorded.  Once  detected, cetaceans (especially sperm whales) are tracked using a dedicated acoustic software.  Photo-identification data are also collected. By taking pictures of particular morphological characteristics, like the trailing edge of dorsal fins or flukes, or the scars on their body, researchers may identify specific individuals. A photo-ID based monitoring system provides crucial information on cetacean distribution, habitat use, population estimate, social structure, seasonal presence, movements and association patterns. The collection of faeces samples is occasionally  performed  from  the  water  surface, in  order to investigate  feeding  habits  of  certain  species.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Marine mammals data collection training programs on the field visual and acoustic data collection, photo-identification, behavioral sampling, fecal sampling and methods for conducting population studies.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: The  study  area is located in the NW Mediterranean Sea and covers  about  25,000  km2  between  Genoa,  Porquerolles  islands,  and  Cape  Corse on the island of Corsica.  The study area is  located within the Pelagos Sanctury for Mediterranean marine mammals, the large protected areas dedicated to the conservation of marine mammals in the Mediterranean.  Ligurian  Sea  presents  both  a  deep-water  and  a  shelf-slope  habitat,   suitable  for  the  breeding  and  foraging  needs  of  eight  commonly  occurring  cetacean  species.  It  has  one  of  the  highest concentrations of whales and dolphins in the Mediterranean. The shallow waters of the continental shelf (0 to 200 m deep) are the preferred habitat of the common bottlenose dolphin (Tursiops truncatus). Deep divers inhabit the continental slope,  (i.e. from  200  to  2000  m).  This  is  the  preferred habitat of sperm whales (Physeter macrocephalus), Risso's dolphins (Grampus griseus) and  Cuvier's  beaked  whales  (Ziphius  cavirostris).  Striped  dolphins  (Stenella  coeruleoalba) are also present in the area. The  pelagic  area  is  defined  as  the open-water  area  where  depth  exceeds  2000  m.  This  is  the  main habitat of fin whales (Balaenoptera physalus), and long-finned pilot whales (Globicephala melas).
duration_moreinfo: With a long-term data set of 30 years, Cetaceans Sanctuary Research Project present on of the most important and long time series of cetaceans data in the Mediterranean Sea.
freq_moreinfo: Data are collected daily in the summer season (from May to September).
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: Data are subjected to OBIS SEAMAP data sharing policy and INTERCET  data sharing policies. The use of the data is subjected to restrictions. Tethys Research Institute (TRI) must be informed about the intention to use of the data by other users. Details needs to be provided and discussed with TRI about the use of the data.
In_OBIS: Yes; more than half but not all of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS
MM_vars_age: Age (year, age class, life history stage)
MM_methods_other: Transects (vessel) did not follow a systematic design with  random probability sampling but were designed as triangles to  cross depth contours as perpendicularly as possible and to cover as much of the area as possible.
MM_protocol_age: Age (year, age class, life history stage)
AnythingElse: I found very interesting the tool you provide to draw the boundary of the study area. Could you please send me a link with more information about the platform/tool? Thanks   Caterina Lanfredi, PhD   Marine Biologist  Tethys Research Institute  Member of the Board of Directors  viale G.B. Gadio, 2   20121 Milano, Italy  https://www.tethys.org

duration_moreinfo: Program is conducted annually.      Channel Islands National park also has a Rocky Intertidal Monitoring program that has been ongoing since 1982
protocols_moreinfo: see: http://www.esapubs.org/archive/ecol/E094/245/    We also have a more detailed protocol/handbook but the above should suffice.

dataaccess_moreinfo: If someone is going to conduct data analysis with raw data, they need to explicitly understand the protocol changes which are well documented in the handbook.  Data requests through the NPS Irma site above are now required.

prog_network: Operates as the Arctic Node within GeoBon
prog_funders: Operated by CAFF and the full list of Board members can be found here: https://www.caff.is/management-board The overall porgramme is co-led by the Kingdom of Denmark and the US, with individual components led by different Arctic States
key_inst: Too many to list see here: https://www.caff.is/management-board And see here for list of partners: https://www.caff.is/cbmp-partners

CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Has biodiversity monitoring plans for both the marine and coastal ecosystems which are being implemented. Works to engage indigenous peoples in its activities
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: See here for the overall area covered: http://geo.abds.is/geonetwork/srv/eng/catalog.search#/metadata/2ad7a7cb-2ad7-4517-a26e-7878ef134239    And see below for more specifics on each ecosystem and what is covered (described in the ecosystem monitoring plans)  Marine: https://www.caff.is/marine  Coastal: https://www.caff.is/coastal  Terrestrial: https://www.caff.is/terrestrial  Freshwater: https://www.caff.is/freshwater
duration_moreinfo: Programme actively synthesizing and aggregating data with latest reports including:  State of the Arctic Freshwater Biodiversity report: https://arcticbiodiversity.is/freshwater  State of the Arctic Marine Biodiversity report: https://arcticbiodiversity.is/marine
freq_moreinfo: The Circumpolar Biodiversity Monitoring Program (CBMP) is an international network of scientists, government agencies, Indigenous organizations and conservation groups working together to harmonize and integrate efforts to monitor the Arctic's living resources.    The CBMP focuses its efforts on five key program areas:    Data management (the Arctic Biodiversity Data Service)  Capacity building  Reporting  Coordination and integration of Arctic monitoring  Communication, education and outreach  CBMP experts are developing four coordinated and integrated Arctic Biodiversity Monitoring Plans to help guide circumpolar monitoring efforts. Results will be channeled into effective conservation, mitigation and adaptation policies supporting the Arctic. These plans represent the Arctic's major ecosystems:    Marine  Freshwater  Terrestrial  Coastal
protocols_moreinfo: See relevant monitoring plans for each ecosystem covered: https://caff.is/monitoring

type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_moreinfo: CLIOTOP’s overarching goal is to facilitate broad-scale comparisons (e.g. over time, space, and taxa) that better identify the impacts of climate and fishing on top predators and the functioning of pelagic ecosystems, with the ultimate goal of developing a predictive capability for the effects of such impacts. Delivering ocean management that addresses these key components requires multi-disciplinary approaches that incorporate physical, ecological, and socio-economic aspects. The CLimate Impacts on TOp Predators (CLIOTOP) science programme (a regional programme of the Integrated Marine Biosphere Research (IMBeR) project), actively support a comparative philosophy and provides efficient avenues for the exploration and attribution of drivers of variability in dynamic pelagic systems to support the development and implementation of adaptive management applications that consider ocean variability and change.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: CLIOTOP supports Several activities, including collaboration-promoting workshops, open science symposia, and dedicated task teams addressing specific topics and runs mentoring programs as part of these activities
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: CLIOTOP is global in its reach, with contributors active in all ocean basins
freq_moreinfo: CLIOTOP contributors use many technologies to investigate the distributions, habitat use, physiology, trophic ecology, dispersion potential, connectivity, climate associations and environmental drivers of the biology and ecology of top predators. These technologies vary in their sampling intervals from minutes through to days/months/years - there is no one standard and no one most common sampling interval as it depends on the question being asked and the top predator being studied
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Limited access- many entities have access to raw data (e.g. something is hindering it being fully open such as a moratorium or a secure login is needed)
dataaccess_moreinfo: CLIOTOP does not hold any data - the contributors to CLIOTOP hold their own data. It is not the role of CLIOTOP to hold or manage contributors data
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: Not CLIOTOPs role - is the role of the institution of the person contributing to CLIOTOP
In_OBIS: I don't know if the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_name: Coral, reef fishes, invertebrates, seagrass and supporting variables monitoring program
prog_funders: SPC, Ministry of Fisheries and Marine Resources Development
funder_moreinfo: Secretariat of the Pacific Community  Noumea  New Caledonia
key_inst: University of British Columbia (Dr Simon Donner) University of California (Dr Jacob Eurich)  These Universities researched in Kiribati sharing their data on corals, finfish and invertebrates and work collaboratively with our Division
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_Directory: Directory of programs/networks/observatories (the program provides information on observing networks/programs)
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Attachment on corals seagrass, finish and invertebrates, : - data collection, data entry and analysis, statistical analysis and report writing.  Capacity building on coral reef reproductive analysis for determining size limit and other essential reproductive information.  Capacity building on using advanced tools, such as database, Statistical tools (R-software or etc), monitoring methods  Capacity building on mapping of corals, invertebrates, finfish and seagrass results using QGIS or other software for producing informative mapping for feeding Marine Spatial Planning information  Buidling capacity on identification zooplanktons and including toxic dinoflagellate causing ciguatera poisoning in seafood  Attachments or training on how to maintain and service scuba tanks and compressors  Building the capacity of our lab technicians to understand all equipment needed for water quality testing, meiobenthos testing, coral reef reproductive analysis, and other observing programs.  Needing of a data specialist or analyst
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: Coastal Fisheries Division or preferably CFD  Ministry of Fisheries and Marine Resources Development  South Tarawa  Kiribati
duration_moreinfo: Ciguatera testing has been undertaken since the 1980s but the testing has been ceased since the expert in zooplankton identification were migrated to work in regional institutions  Under the World Bank funding for Coastal Fisheries Programmes 2020 - 2025 we have been proposed the need to sample ciguatera, water quality, reef fish reproductive analysis and etc to be funded including the equipment and laboratory set up
freq_moreinfo: For the Creel Survey on fishermen catches to monitor reef fishes and pelagic of high commercial values in terms of their length weight frequency, CPUE and other socio-economic  related issue
protocols_moreinfo: Coralcover - Mean percent cover using CPCe software  Finfish - Mean density and biomass per hectare or squared meter which adopted from SPC survey protocol  Invertebrates - Mean density per hectare of squared meter which also adopted from SPC (Secretariat of the Pacific Community)  Seagrass cover - Mean coverage using quadrat adopted from USP (University of the South Pacific)

funder_moreinfo: The program is primarily funded through recurrent state government funding, but is occasionally added to with funds from external sources such as University grants, ARC research funding or Industry partners.

spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: The program manages hundreds of sampling sites across Western Australia's marine park network, that cover a number of key ecological values (fish and sharks, coral, seagrass, macroalgae, mangroves, penguins, Australian sea lions, dolphins, crocodiles, macro-invertebrates) and environmental variables (seawater temperature). Unfortunately I do not have the time to compile this entire list. As such, I have just put polygons around the areas in which will sample.
duration_moreinfo: The program was sporadic prior to 2010 but has been more coordinated and with more intensive and periodic sampling since.

duration_moreinfo: While most of our sites/areas have been visited only once  a few have been sampled over time particularly two benthic sites in the Rockall Trough west of Scotland  - "Station M" 1974 to 2015 and "Permanent station" 1976 to 1991

vars_moreinfo: Many of the variables above are sampled by other researchers in the SAMS including some from the benthic study areas.
AnythingElse: Most of our benthic invertebrates sampled are stored preserved at the SAMS, Oban, Argyll, Scotland. Selected specimens are in the national collections at the Natural History Museum, London and the National Museums of Scotland, Edinburgh. SAMS staff also sampled fish and zooplankton particularly from the Rockall Trough. Our data contact person is Steve Gontarek, Head of IT, steve.gontarek@sams.ac.uk. The areas of sampling indicated on the world map by rectangles are approximate as co-ordinates would take too much time to plot.
alldataproviders: Raw data collector/provider (observatory/site/program collects data) NA

prog_funders: National Geographic Society
key_inst: MIT Media Lab Open Ocean Initiative (capacity-building and technology transfer)
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_moreinfo: We are collecting raw data, and also training other entities to use the technology to collect their own data. We aggregate all data collected, and create products, such as manuscripts. In the near future, we will be providing contributions to OBIS and public-facing products such as ESRI online maps.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: For the past two years we have been conducting short-course trainings for student and research groups with limited research capacity, and also loaning the technology to these groups for their use. In the near future we would like to expand these short-courses to include a module on marine science leadership and science communication, so that trainees can collect data, and also lead their own discoveries.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: Currently we have very broad spatial coverage, but no long-term data at one site. We are developing partnerships, for example with Lindblad Expeditions, to be able to sample the same sites over multiple years.
freq_moreinfo: We are sampling data at least quarterly, but not at the same sites. Therefor I elected "opportunistically" instead of quarterly.
protocols_moreinfo: So far the tool has been used for exploration, and the operating procedures have been flexible to fit with the expedition schedule. This year we will be performing operating procedure field tests to determine best practices. We do use standard operating procedures and best practices for data annotation, however, things like video recording time and bait type have differed over the course of the program.

funder_moreinfo: The DBO is endorsed by the United States Interagency Arctic Science Policy Committee (IAPRC) and with the US Arctic Research Plan. In addition, it is endorsed by the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC) and the Pacific Arctic Group  (PAG).
key_inst: University of Washington Seattle, WA; Clark University, Worcester, MA; NOAA Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory, Seattle, WA; University of Victoria, Canada; Institute of Ocean Sciences, Department of Fisheries and Oceans Canada, Sidney, BC; Korean Polar Research Institute (KOPRI), Inchen, South Korea; Polar Research Institute of China, Shanghai, China; Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology (JAMSTEC), Yokosuka, Japan; Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Woods Hole, MA; Arctic Data Center, Santa Barbara, CA; School of Fisheries and Ocean Sciences, University of Alaska Fairbanks, AK; others for different US agencies and international Pacific Arctic Group partners
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_moreinfo: The Pacific Arctic region is experiencing major reductions in seasonal sea ice and increases in sea surface temperatures. A key uncertainty is how the marine ecosystem will respond to these shifts in the timing of spring sea ice retreat and/or delays in fall sea ice formation. Variations in upper-ocean water hydrography, stratification, light penetration, planktonic and benthic production, pelagic-benthic coupling, and upper trophic level migration patterns are all influenced by sea ice and temperature changes. In order to evaluate these responses, the Distributed Biological Observatory (DBO) was initiated in 2010 as a change detection array for the identification and consistent monitoring of biophysical responses to environmental change in the Arctic (Moore and Grebmeier 2018, Arctic 71; Grebmeier et al. 2019, Deep Sea Res II 162). Repeat sampling each year is undertaken through multiple international occupations of transect lines and bounding boxes via oceanographic research cruises. Continuous data collections are also obtained annually through mooring and satellite observations. Shared data and periodic data workshops allow evaluation of data sets and collaborative discussions. The Pacific DBO activities focus on 5 regional biological transects located at biological hotspots along a latitudinal gradient in the northern Bering and Chukchi seas. Three additional locations were designated in the Beaufort Sea in 2015, with expansion plans including DBO sites in the Baffin Bay/Davis Strait region, the Atlantic sector of the northern Barents Sea, and possibly into the Russian Arctic.  Spatial and temporal time series, ecosystem-level observations provide increased understanding of the phenology of sea ice growth and retreat, hydrographic characteristics, seasonal plankton development, carbon export and pelagic-benthic coupling, benthic population change, and connection of prey to upper trophic level predators. Development of the DBO is proving to be a significant resource for the identification and consistent monitoring of biophysical responses in the changing Arctic for decision makers and the general public.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Since the original development of the 5 transect lines in the Pacific Arctic in 2010 the DBO network has expanded into the US and Canadian Beaufort Seas for time series data collections. In addition, an Atlantic DBO in the Barents Sea is under development with international collaborators as is placed of DBO lines in the Davis Strait/Baffin Bay region between Canada and Greenland. We have also initiated discussions with Russian colleagues for a potential DBO effort.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: We have set stations and bounding boxes for the time series DBO sampling in the Pacific Arctic.
duration_moreinfo: The DBO was initiated in 2010 as a change detection array for the identification and consistent monitoring of biophysical responses to environmental change in the Arctic (Moore and Grebmeier 2018, Arctic 71; Grebmeier et al. 2019, Deep Sea Res II 162). Some of the DBO sites were initiated back in the 1980s and form the initial retrospective data for the effort.
freq_moreinfo: The DBO network consists of multiple ship-based occupations annually (2-6 cruises  per year). In addition, we have moorings in most of the DBO sites, some with sediment traps and water samplers. We also have NASA producing satellite products for the region, with statistics done on the DBO bounding box regions.
protocols_moreinfo: QA/QC is undertaken on the data collections by participants and the data submitted to national archives. Standard procedures have been shared through development of the program and periodic data workshops. For the US, the core NSF data archive is the Arctic Data Center  (ADC; . Currently a revised DBO-focused project page is under development at the ADC.

dataaccess_restriction_level: NA
dataaccess_moreinfo: International DBO data sets are retain by the country, but accessible with time limits. We are developing a matrix of DBO data sites and weblinks/points of contact for posting on a new DBO data set at the Chesapeake Biological Laboratory/UMCES.
In_OBIS: Yes; more than half but not all of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

spatial_moreinfo: The Ecosystem Monitoring (EcoMon) Program conducts multi-species plankton surveys, and sampling effort covered the entire Northeast US Shelf from Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, to Cape Sable, Nova Scotia, four to six times per year. EcoMon uses a random-stratified design based on the Northeast Fisheries Science Center bottom trawl survey design. The number of plankton strata (n = 47) is lower than the bottom trawl survey (n = 108) as the narrow inshore stratum and the offshore shelf-break stratum of the bottom trawl survey were combined in the EcoMon plankton sampling design. The area encompassed by each stratum determined the number of samples in that stratum.  Plankton samples are collected both day and night using a 61-cm bongo net. Net tow speed is approximately 1.5 knots. Double oblique tows are a minimum of 5-minutes in duration, and fished from the surface to within 5-m of the seabed or to a maximum depth of 200-m. The volume filtered of all collections is measured with mechanical flowmeters mounted across the mouth of each net.  A Conductivity, Temperature, and Depth (CTD) instrument can is paired with the bongo net to collect data concurrently to the plankton sampling. We also sample with CTDs at fixed stations to collect water samples with a Rosette sampler. Samples are analyzed for carbonate water chemistry and nutrient levels from from different water depths.

type_moreinfo: MOOSE is a national program funded by CNRS-INSU and French Ministry. It is included in a national Research Infrastructure called ILICO supported by CNRS and IFREMER. MOOSE and ILICO supports DYFAMED time series and biological EOV.  EMSO is a European Research Infrastructure Consortium (ERIC) supporting DYFAMED mooring and sediment traps collection.

prog_name: Environmental Sample Processor network in Lake Erie
prog_funders: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Environmental Protection Agency, Great Lakes Observing System
funder_moreinfo: NOAA provides the main support for the ESP network, however, EPA and GLOS have provide funds to purchase the instrumentation and for equipment maintenance.
key_inst: NOAA/National Ocean Service/National Centers for Coastal Ocean Science,  Cooperative Institute for Great Lakes Research
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_moreinfo: The ESP observing program via the ESP collects data regarding cyanobacteria toxins from two stations within the Great Lakes, continuously from July - Oct.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: Only one site has been active since 2017.  In 2020 we will activate the second site.
freq_moreinfo: Two samples per day at sunrise sampling from approximately 1 m above the bottom of the lake and at 11 am from approximately 1 m below the surface.  Sampling only occurs during the active cyanobacteria bloom season from July - Oct.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: No, the raw data are publicly accessible/open.
dataaccess_restriction_level: NA
In_OBIS: No; none of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_funders: none - self funded
key_inst: None.
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: It is an academic/public/industry/policy hybrid. I (CWP) am a marine researcher and eOceans provides the platform for researchers (myself, others, industry, community groups, ngo's, etc), to collect, manage, and analyze data. We (myself and the communities/organizations/individuals that solicited the research) collaborate on interpretation and write-up for publication.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: We provide capacity development to the communities we serve - giving them the insights they need (conservation, tourism optimization, etc.).
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: Sampling location is on a project by project (team) basis. Great Fiji Shark count is hundreds of sites in Fiji; eShark Thailand is hundreds of sites in Fiji; eManta was 90 cells around the world; Shark Sanctuary Assessment was 38 countries... each question/hypotheis requires different spatial boundaries.
duration_moreinfo: In the past it's been project by project, but now we have a system for ongoing monitoring of biological and their impacts (e.g., anthropogenic features).
freq_moreinfo: Users provide sub-daily check-ins of ecological, environmental, and socioeconomic conditions.
protocols_moreinfo: We keep it simple - don't collect data that can be misinterpreted (e.g., depth) or ones that have too much variability between observers (e.g., habitat). Follow best practices for endangered species when sharing/publishing to ensure they are not put at risk.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Restricted access- only data provider and another entity (e.g. contractor) have access to raw data
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: It is the wishes of the users/subscribers, based on hundreds of interviews. If individuals want to share their data, they can.
data_aggregators_list: No - but, we are in the process of designing features that will help users decide what data to make available and to share those to OBIS following best practices for endangered species and special places.
In_OBIS: Yes; less than half of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

vars_moreinfo: Also collect potentially impacting anthropogenic variables (pollution, plastics, etc.) and socioeconomic and cultural values (what part of the world's oceans that people are using/valuing and for what.
MM_methods_other: Stationary point counts, belt-transects, roving; proxies for noise (for now) including number and types of boats.
MM_protocol_other: It's more on the data side. We collect all data and, depending on the question, parse the data accordingly.

prog_funders: Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile, CONICYT
funder_moreinfo: The multiples monitoring programs are not funded by any dedicated grant.  They are funded by research grants 'of opportinity' and other research funds of interested professors
key_inst: International Long Term Socio Ecological Network, CEAZA (climatological data), World Association of Marine Sites,
type_moreinfo: MOnitoring programs of biological variables and high-frequency sea surface temperature (SST)
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: Sampling sites located in central Chile. Most intertidal rocky shores. Some shallow subtidal habitats
duration_moreinfo: The monitoring program has maintained some of the variables since 1998. Several have been terminated due to lack of funding (e.g. daily chlorophyll, bird surveys, subtidal dissolved oxygen, etc)
freq_moreinfo: In the Table of sites we ahve indicated the frequency. It varies from subdaily (minutes) to yearly, depending on the type of variable monitored
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: Physical data (SST, Wind velocity, Dissolved Oxygen) have been deposited in CENDHOC  and CEAZAMET  Biological data are under different levels of data restriction depending on the time series.
In_OBIS: No; none of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_funders: European Commision infrastructure programs (EMBRC, AssemblePlus), European Commision Interreg program (GEANS), Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management
funder_moreinfo: Currently we have the following networks, projects and infrastrucutre programs contributing to the European ARMS program:     1. European Interreg program GEANS (https://northsearegion.eu/geans/)  2. Genomic Observatories Network (http://genomicobservatories.org/) and Genomics Standards Consortium  (gensc.org)  3. EU marine infrastructyure program AssemblePlus (http://www.assembleplus.eu/) and EMBRC (http://www.embrc.eu/)   4. Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (https://www.havochvatten.se/en)  5. LifeWatch infrastructure for Biodiversity Data (http://Lifewatch.eu and http://Lifewatch.be)
key_inst: British Antarctic Survey, UK (Antarctica); Marine Biological Association of the UK (British channel, Plymouth); Marine Biological Station Roscoff, France (British channel, Roscoff); University of Vigo, Spain (Atlantic coast, Vigo); Tvärminne Zoological Station, Finland (Baltic Sea, Gulf of Finland); Marine Biology Station Piran, Slovenia (Mediterranean, Gulf of Piran); University of Galway, Ireland (Atlantic Ocean, Irish West coast); Institute of Oceanology in Gdansk, Svalbard (Svalbard); University of Gdansk, Poland (Baltic Sea, Gdansk bay); University of Gothenburg, Sweden (North Sea, Skagerrak, Koster National Park); Flanders Institute of Marine Research, Belgium (North Sea - Belgian coast); Helenic Center for Marine Research, Greece (Mediterranean, Crete); Hebrew University of Jerusalem Interuniversity Institute for Marine Sciences in Eilat, Israel (Red Sea, Gulf of Aqaba); University of Arhus, Denmark (Greenland, east and west); University of Arhus, Denmark (North Sea, Danish West coast and Kattegat); University of the Basque Country, Spain (Atlantic coast, Bilbao, Bay of Biscay); Nord University, Norway (Norwegian west coast);
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_moreinfo: We are primarly coordinating the raw data collection, but are integrated with Data infrastructures and aggregators (e.g. LifeWatch.be) as well as Standards organisations (e.g. http://genomicobservatories.org/, gensc.org).
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: We have resources to develop manuals and tutorials for genetic monitoring using ARMS as well as for Data management and training between 2029-2022.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
freq_moreinfo: We have 2 activities:  1. short-term deployments (4-6 months over the summer seasons) to detect NIS  2. Long-term deployments (12 montsh deployed/collected during spring) for biological monitoring
protocols_moreinfo: we use this program to develop SOPs
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Limited access- many entities have access to raw data (e.g. something is hindering it being fully open such as a moratorium or a secure login is needed)
dataaccess_moreinfo: in the long run we want to make all data open acessible with a one year moratorium. But at this stage we are working on the data manegement issues. this will take another year, then we should have stable data flows and can make raw data open access very quickly.
data_aggregators_list: Sequence Read Archive (raw sequences)   GeneBank (cleaned, annotated sequences)  Image data Marine Data Archive at VLIZ/LifeWatch.be)  Metadata incl. upstream and downstream protocols and ABS documents (Marine Data Archive at VLIZ/LifeWatch.be)  Downstream species hypotheses (GBIF)

type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_moreinfo: In EMBOS the needed large scale network of research locations in Europe has been developed to assess long-term changes in marine biodiversity and their possible causes taking into account natural and anthropogenic gradients.   The project has been funded by COST and resulted in a pan-European network of 41 observatories (locations) for the sustained observation of different Essential Ocean Variables of different habitats. Funding has ceased in 2015. Within EMBOS+ the consortium is looking for funds to extend and optimize this observatory system, including novel interdisciplinary approaches for marine (biodiversity) research.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: EMBOS has resulted in a pan-European network of 50 observatories at 40 locations for the sustained observation of different Essential Ocean Variables of different habitats.
duration_moreinfo: After the end of the COST action, the EMBOS+ consortium continued the activities in a slimmed down approach. Recently the activities have been put on hold. The consortium is looking for external funds to support fieldwork and further development of the network.

prog_name: French Observation and Monitoring program for Phytoplankton and Hydrology in coastal waters
prog_network: REPHY is a national monitoring program contributing to the National Observation Service PHYTOBS (network). REPHY is also complemented with regional monitoring program (supported by IFREMER) : SRN (Regional nutrient monitoring, Hauts de France), RHLN (Biological and hydrological monitoring, Normandy), ARCHYD (Arcachon hydrological monitoring), RSLHYD (Phytoplankton and hydrology monitoring in mediterranean lagoons)
prog_funders: IFREMER, AFB (French Agency for Biodiversity), Food and Agriculture Ministry, Water Agency of Artois-Picardie, Water Agency of Seine-Normandie, Water Agency of Loire-Bretagne, Water Agency of Adour-Garonne, Water Agency of Rhône-Méditerranée-Corse
key_inst: CNRS (French National Center for Scientific Research), Marine Universities, National Observation Services PHYTOBS, National Observation Services SOMLIT, National Observation Services Coast-HF, INSU (French National Universe Science Institute)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_Directory: Directory of programs/networks/observatories (the program provides information on observing networks/programs)
type_moreinfo: This program contributes to adress scientific issues. It also produces inputs for the Water Frame Directive and for health risk assessment.Data available here:  https://doi.org/10.17882/47248 . It includes monitoring of micro-phytoplankton, salinity, temperature, turbidity, chlorophylle a, dissolved oxygen, NH4, NO3, NO2, PO4, SiOH4
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
freq_moreinfo: 36 sampling location are sampled fortnightly (26x per year), 54 sampling location are sampled monthly to quarterly (WFD), 61 sampling location are sampled quarterly and 64 sampling location are sampled according to the health risk context (ie toxigenic phytoplankton in the water and/or toxins in shellfish).
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: No, the raw data are publicly accessible/open.

dataaccess_moreinfo: SURVAL is a portal allowing acces to data. REPHY biological data are stored in a database called Quadrige. Any potential user of these data is allowed to attend a training course on how to extrat raw data directly form the database.
In_OBIS: Yes; all of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_funders: Smithsonian Institution, MarineGEO, NOAA
key_inst: NOAA, ASSEMBLE+, MARINEGEO, AIMS
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_Directory: Directory of programs/networks/observatories (the program provides information on observing networks/programs)
type_moreinfo: The Global ARMS Program centralizes and makes available information and documentation on the ARMS (Autonomous Reef Monitoring Structures) and standardized processing protocols. The program curates a database of worldwide ARMS deployments that can be searched freely on the ARMS portal.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: The Global ARMS Program can help with capacity building and training workshops. We distribute ARMS units from a centralized facility to reduce per unit costs and have funding to help coordinate regional nodes and training workshops for deployments, recoveries and processing. Moreover, NMNH can host visiting researchers for training in sample processing, library preparation and data generation.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: sampling is site specific - ARMS are deployed for a period of time and recovered, they act as time-averaged biodiversity monitoring stations for benthic communities
protocols_moreinfo: The key is the use Autonomous Reef Monitoring Structures (ARMS) as standardized collection units. Protocols are found on the website and on Protocols.io
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Restricted access- only data provider and another entity (e.g. contractor) have access to raw data
dataaccess_moreinfo: Not an easy answer here - ARMS partners currently control their own raw data - we are in discussion about data availability and standard formats (BIOM files)
data_aggregators_list: We intend the data to go to OBIS/GBIF - ASV/OTU taxonomic annotations as presence/absence data
In_OBIS: No; none of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS
