prog_name: Gulf of Maine North Atlantic Time Series
prog_funders: NASA
key_inst: Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences
type_moreinfo: The goals of GNATS are two-fold: 1) to provide calibration/validation of remote sensing data for bio-optical, biological, chemical and physical variables, sampled from NASA satellite sensors and 2) to create a time series of these same variables across the widest portion of the Gulf of Maine.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: Our transect time series falls along the line connecting Portland, Maine, USA with Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, Canada
protocols_moreinfo: Methods can be found here:  Balch, W.M., D.T. Drapeau, B.C. Bowler, E.S. Booth, J.I. Goes, A. Ashe, and J.M. Frye. 2004. A multi-year record of hydrographic and bio-optical properties in the Gulf of Maine:  I. Spatial and temporal variability. Prog. Oceanog. 63:57-98.  Balch, W.M., D.T. Drapeau, B.C. Bowler, E.S. Booth, L.A. Windecker, and A. Ashe. 2008. Space-time variability of carbon standing stocks and fixation rates in the Gulf of Maine, along the GNATS transect between Portland, ME and Yarmouth, NS. J. Plankton Res. 30:119-139.  Balch, W.M., D.T. Drapeau, B.C. Bowler, and T. Huntington. 2012. Step-changes in the physical, chemical and biological characteristics of the Gulf of Maine, as documented by the GNATS time series. Marine Ecology - Progress Series. 450:11–35.  Balch, W.M., T. Huntington, G. Aiken, D.T. Drapeau, B.C. Bowler, L. Lubelczyk, and K. Butler. 2016. Towards a quantitative and empirical dissolved organic carbon budget for the Gulf of Maine, a semi-enclosed shelf sea. Global Biogeochem. Cycles. 30:doi: 10.1002/2015GB005332.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: No, the raw data are publicly accessible/open.

prog_name: Gulf of Mexico Dolphin Identification System
prog_funders: Disney Worldwide Conservation Fund (previous), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, Harbor Branch Oceanographic Institute
key_inst: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1smTECAA_Pgv_Ma5HzDfEt13hSPJss6R0Mziqgs2PHsA/edit?usp=sharing
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)

CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Capacity development will be achieved in the sense that combining photo-ID data from around the Gulf will give better understanding as to individual animal movement patterns and habitat usage, also by ensuring the archival of photo-identification data that may otherwise be lost (graduate student work, historical datasets).  By continuing to collect data from collaborators we provide a useful decision-making tool for managers.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: We aim to include data from Puerto Rico and the western Caribbean (off Yucatan peninsula and Belize) in the future.
duration_moreinfo: Time scale for contributors varies greatly
freq_moreinfo: This is not an accurate answer as we collect from many different sources with different methods for data sampling
protocols_moreinfo: Each contributor collects data within their own system and GoMDIS standardizes similar data types
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Limited access- many entities have access to raw data (e.g. something is hindering it being fully open such as a moratorium or a secure login is needed)
dataaccess_moreinfo: Collaborators which have contributed data are able to view other collaborator data- however usage (publication, reports) is NOT allowed without consent from contributing organiziations.
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: GoMDIS is a repository- this would not be feasible to achieve without consent from all parties.  Tabled for future discussion.
In_OBIS: Yes; less than half of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_funders: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, National Science Foundation, North Pacific Research Board, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Auke Bay Labs and Kasitsna Bay Lab, U.S. Geological Survey Alaska Science Center, National Park Service, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
funder_moreinfo: After extensive restoration, research, and monitoring efforts in the two decades following the Exxon Valdez oil spill (EVOS), scientists and the EVOS Trustee Council recognize that full recovery from the spill will take decades. Long-term monitoring of the spill-affected resources is important for assessing the recovery of injured species, and for managing those resources and the services they provide.    Gulf Watch Alaska is the long-term ecosystem monitoring program of the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council. The Gulf Watch Alaska Program aims to provide sound scientific data and products that inform management agencies and the public of changes in the environment and the impacts of these changes on injured resources.
key_inst: University of Alaska (Fairbanks, Anchorage, Southeast), Kachemak Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve, North Gulf Oceanic Society, Marine Biological Association, Axiom Data Science, Institute for Seabird Research and Conservation, Alaska Ocean Observing System
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: Gulf Watch Alaska collects long-term monitoring data on environmental drivers, nearshore, and pelagic ecosystems in the northern Gulf of Alaska from Prince William Sound to the Katmai coast.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Data collected by Gulf Watch Alaska projects are made publicly available through the AOOS Gulf of Alaska Data Portal and are published to DataONE in five year increments.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: Some projects within the program began sampling long before 2012. The projects coalesced into one program beginning in 2012. Some projects began in the 1970s, others in the 1980s, and others in the 1990s. Several projects began in 2012 with the start of the program.
freq_moreinfo: Selecting one sampling frequency for the program is highly problematic because different projects within the program collect data sub-daily, daily, monthly, quarterly, 2x per year, or 1x per year.
protocols_moreinfo: All projects have standard operating procedures. They vary by project. All data are reviewed for quality control before they are made publicly available.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: No, the raw data are publicly accessible/open.
dataaccess_restriction_level: NA
dataaccess_moreinfo: While the data are publicly available, we request that users contact the principal investigators of the projects to gain additional understanding about the data before using in analyses/publications.

prog_name: IMOS National Reference Stations monthly Biogeochemical sampling
prog_funders: CSIRO, AIMS, SARDI, NSW DEH
funder_moreinfo: The funders listed are those that are responsible for the sampling at at least one NRS.
key_inst: SIMS run one component of the sampling for each site, collection and analysis of larval fish.
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: IMOS do not fund proof of concept but encouragesfor innovative methods, i.e. molecular/eDNA data collection
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: The sites were set to provide a broad national coverage, whilst limited within the logistical possibilities.
duration_moreinfo: This now provides a 10 year time series for biological and geochemical parameters, most of which are EOVs
freq_moreinfo: 5 of the 7 stations sample 12 times a year.   Kangaroo Island samples 5 times a year as it is severely weather dependent  Darwin Harbour samples 4 times in 24 period twice a year (tidal effects) and 2 six monthly samplings.
protocols_moreinfo: Eriksen Ruth S., Davies Claire H., Bonham Pru, Coman Frank E., Edgar Steven, McEnnulty Felicity R., McLeod David, Miller Margaret J., Rochester Wayne, Slotwinski Anita, Tonks Mark L., Uribe-Palomino Julian, Richardson Anthony J. 2019. Australia’s Long-Term Plankton Observations: The Integrated Marine Observing System National Reference Station Network, Frontiers in Marine Science,  6 :161		  https://www.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fmars.2019.00161        DOI=10.3389/fmars.2019.00161        http://imos.org.au/facilities/nationalmooringnetwork/moorings-documentation/  BGC sampling manual available here
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: No, the raw data are publicly accessible/open.
dataaccess_restriction_level: NA
dataaccess_moreinfo: Go to the portal and write NRS in the keyword search.   All the associated data files will be listed.
In_OBIS: Yes; all of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

Zooplankton_biomass_dataproduct: Data products from this variable are developed by the network
Zooplankton_diversity_dataproduct: Data products from this variable are developed by the network
vars_moreinfo: A CTD cast and a secchi are conducted at each sampling event.  Nutrients, salinity, pigments, Total Alkalinity and Total carbon , microbes, TSS (inorganic/organic), microbes are collected and analyses from Niskin bottles.  Zooplankton nets are used for biomass, composition, size structure and genetics.  Phytoplankton sample is collected from the niskin water.  Larval fish tows are also conducted.  Further information is available in the manual.  WQM's are attached to the mooring, surface and ~20m.
AnythingElse: Most of it is encompassed in the manual.  http://imos.org.au/facilities/nationalmooringnetwork/moorings-documentation/

funder_moreinfo: NCRIS is a national network of world-class research infrastructure projects that support high-quality research that will drive greater innovation in the Australian research sector and the economy more broadly.
key_inst: University of Tasmania(lead), Curtin University, Australian Institute of Marine Science, CSIRO,  Sydney Institute of Marine Science (University of Sydney, University of Technology Sydney, University of New South Wales,  Macquarie University), South Australian Research and Development Institute, Bureau of Meteorology, University of Western Australia, Australian Antarctic Division, Deakin University

type_moreinfo: IMOS is Australia's national observing program and includes observations from open ocean to coast and in all disciplines of marine science

spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)

freq_moreinfo: Depending on our platform it could be daily (underway sampling) or every minute (moored sensors) or sampling monthly or quarterly. The options are limited to only one answser  which is not helpful
protocols_moreinfo: We have protocols and some have been published in ocean best practice repository with others in the pipeline

dataaccess_moreinfo: Some raw data are in the portal, however, the rest is available upon request. This is because some data are too complex to serve and will not be of use (bio-acoustics for example)
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: Some data need to be cleaned. Raw data implies lack of QC

prog_funders: EU (Interreg Italy-France), Regione Liguria, Regione Toscana, Regione Sardegna, Provincia di Livorno, Office de l'Environnement de la Corse, Costa Edutainment S.p.A., Fondazione Acquario di Genova
funder_moreinfo: Intercet (www.intercet.it) is a Web-Gis platform, designed by Acquario di Genova for Regione Liguria within GIONHA (Governance and Integrated Observation of marine Natural Habitat) a project funded by the EU Cross Border Cooperation Programme Italy - France. The management of Intercet (owned by Regione Liguria) was given to Fondazione  Acquario di Genova following a not onerous agreement with Regione Liguria and the original partners of GIONHA (Liguria, Regione Toscana, Regione Sardegna, Provincia di Livorno, Office de l'Environnement de la Corse).

prog_name: IOC-WESTPAC Ocean Remote Sensing Project for Coastal Habitat Mapping
prog_funders: Japan Fund in Trust for UNESCO, The University of Tokyo, Kitasato University
key_inst: AtmspheThe University of Tokyo, Kitasato University, Hasanuddin University, LIPI, Institute of Oceanography of Vietnam, Prince of Sonklar University, Brapha University, University Technology Malyasia, University Malaysia Terengganu
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Standardizing habitat mapping methods using satellite remote sensing including ground truthing methods in IOC-WESTPAC ORSP.  Organizing workshops for ORSP members and also local training course for students and young researchers in members' countries.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
freq_moreinfo: We conduct retrospective LANDSAT image analysis to find long-term changes in coastal habitats.
protocols_moreinfo: We apply depth invariant index (Lyzenga, 1989) or bottom reflectance index proposed by Sagawa et al. (2010) for atmosphere and water column corrections. The protocol will be published in "Coastal Marine Science" soon.

prog_funders: Ocean Care, Foundation Segré
key_inst: Tethys Research Institute
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: The Ionian Dolphin Project aims to ensure the long-term viability of marine mammals living in coastal waters of the eastern Ionian Sea.  Tethys Research Institute is providing support to conservation efforts, through actions including:  continued monitoring of marine mammals through field research methods including boat surveys and individual photo-identification, to detect population trends and identify critical habitat; research on factors threatening the local ecosystems, particularly excessive fishing; as well as public awareness, education and capacity building initiatives (e.g. involvement of a large number of students and volunteers, public awareness events organised locally, public presentations, lectures at local schools, production of multimedia);
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: In the open waters of the Ionian Sea, data collection started in 1991. In the Gulf of Ambracia in 2000. Both on-going.
freq_moreinfo: Daily surveys conducted primarily between june-september although in some years the efforts has been year-round (in the case of the Gulf of Ambracia)
protocols_moreinfo: Surveys at sea conducted from a RIB with at least two observers onboard and with sea condition of Beaufort 3 or less.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: We have shared data on numerous occasions and we have contributed to OBIS Sea Map and other similar platforms. Typically, sharing data takes place in the context of a collaboration between institutions, project partners, etc...
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: Yes, but through a request and mutual agreement between our institution and the data recipient on the use of it. See above.
In_OBIS: Yes; more than half but not all of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

type_moreinfo: Sites belonging to the LTER-Italy network set autonomously their observing and research activities. Moreover, they are coordinated at a national, European and International levels for what concern organizational issues.

spatial_moreinfo: The csv file and the answers to this survey are referred to the marine and coastal (transitional) components of the LTER-Italy network, which comprises also transitional sites.
freq_moreinfo: Each site is characterized by a different sampling frequency. For further details, please visit https://deims.org/network/italy-lter-italia and check for the single sites metadata.
protocols_moreinfo: Actually, the LTER-Italy network follows the suggestions form the LTER Europe network to use OGC (Open Geospatial Consortium) specifications (e.g. Sensor Observation Services SOS and SensorML for sensors description).

AnythingElse: Given the peculiarity of the IMMA network, I am unsure whether I have answered everywhere correctly. But I am available for more in-depth contribution, if applicable and desirable.

prog_funders: NO official funding agents - each activity or project/programme must raise the needed finances.
key_inst: Employers of all PSG members contribute staff time and other resources to run the network (travel to meetings, research programmes driving data collection etc).
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: The scientists involved in the network are data collectors, and analysts. But - in the context of PSG we serve a reporting and consulting function. PSG does the Red List for all pinnipeds for IUCN, but also consults widely on pinniped-related conservation issues.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: PSG members have graduate students and our programmes intermittantly employ people for specific projects - which involves profession training.
spatial_options: Option 3: The network/program samples biological variables using only satellite data so has global coverage
spatial_moreinfo: The satellite data only is NOT true for the PSG - but we do GLOBAL observations, reporting of all pinniped populations status and abundance (where known).
duration_moreinfo: Data collection for the network depends on national sampling or international science projects. The frequency of data collection and updates is highly variable for the different pinniped species or populations. Some have regular survey intervals, while others have never been surveyed.
freq_moreinfo: We update the status of subpopulations (populations and species) at 5 year intervals for the Red List.
protocols_moreinfo: Surveys and biological data collection follow best community practise which is quite standard for pinnipeds. Additionally, the IUCN has very set criteria for biological data such as age at maturity, survivorship etc.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: No, the raw data are publicly accessible/open.
dataaccess_restriction_level: NA
dataaccess_moreinfo: Metadata and classifications are routinely picked-up from our site(s) and used in scientific syntheses - but our "data" is not in the form of a database in any classical sense.
data_aggregators_list: conservation assessments, climate change impacts assessments
In_OBIS: I don't know if the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS
Marine_Mammal_abundance_aggregate: Network aggregates data for this variable
Marine_Mammal_distribution_aggregate: Network aggregates data for this variable
MM_vars_age: Age (year, age class, life history stage)
MM_protocol_age: Age (year, age class, life history stage)
MM_protocol_RepeatedIndivPres: Repeated individual presence (e.g., tracking, resights, photo-id)
MM_protocol_other: Our network does not itself define best-practise - we use published information mostly and assess grey literature for best practise. If we do not trust the methods the data is not accepted into our assessments.
AnythingElse: PSG does not generate data collection, though it stimulates it - and aggregates data into subpopulation, population, subspecies and species assessments. The latter two categories are done completely for all pinniped species by the PSG. Threatened taxa receive additional effort, with reporting ideally at the population level.
alldataproviders: NA Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)

prog_name: La Perouse West Coast of Vancouver Island Plankton Monitoring Program
prog_funders: Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Government of Canada)
key_inst: Line P program (Fisheries and Oceans Canada), Salish Sea monitoring program (Fisheries and Oceans Canada)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_moreinfo: This observing program is an oceanographic monitoring survey of the coastal margin of southern British Columbia, Canada. The survey is focused on water column properties (temperature, salinity, dissolved oxygen, nutrients, etc.,) and plankton abundance/biomass along several shelf-offshore transects extending from southern Vancouver Island to Hecate Strait, BC in the north. The program started in 1979. Sampling currently takes place twice a year in May/June and August/September.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: The monitoring program started with stations/transects in the southern La Perouse region in 1979 and has been progressively extended north since. Most of the current survey stations have been sampled since at least 1998.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: Raw biological (plankton) data is typically available within 3-5 years of collection and/or enumeration.
data_aggregators_list: Open Canada, OBIS, IGMETS, SoG Data Centre

prog_funders: Flanders- Department of Science, Economy and Innovation; Flanders Research Foundation
key_inst: LTER, Genomics observatories, EMBRC, Jerico
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_moreinfo: With the support of Flanders to LifeWatch, VLIZ has a.o. developed a Marine Observatory. It aims to collect scientific data with innovative technology in an automated manner, and to make these data freely available to all potential users. On the one hand, several innovative devices to map phytoplankton (Flow Cytometer) and zooplankton (Video Plankton Recorder) are used during monthly campaigns in the Belgian part of the North Sea. On the other hand, four passive networks register and detect the presence of larger organisms (birds, porpoises, bats and fish) with a minimal human effort.

prog_name: Long Term Ecological Reseach (PELD) at the ILTER site Tamandaré - Spatial and temporal dynamics of marine ecosystems: connectivity, resilience and sustainable use in Southern Pernambuco.
prog_funders: CNPq - Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico, CAPES - Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior, APA Costa dos Corais Fund (Fundação SOS MATA ATL NTICA, Fundação TOYOTA and ICMBio), RARE - Fish Forever (from 2018-2019), Petrobrás Ambiental (from 2018-2019), FACEPE - Fundação de Amparo a Ciência e Tecnologia do Estado de Pernambuco, Serrapilheira Instituto, Rufford Small Grants and RDL/LAVAZZA, Marie Sklodowska-Curie Actions - MSCA, Research and Innovation Staff Exchange - RISE
key_inst: CEPENE - Centro Nacional de Pesquisa e Conservação da Biodiversidade Marinha do Nordeste, ICMBio
type_moreinfo: The program is a research project with some continuous observations (monitoring) and some periodic experiment.  It aims to study seascape ecology in space and time and its relation to natural and anthropogenic impacts.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: The network started in 1999 but some data collection was intermittent, fund driven.
freq_moreinfo: Data collection and sampling frequency are highly dependable on the variable. PELD TAMS performs mainly three sampling frequencies:  * monthly,  * 1x every 2 to 5 years  * Opportunistically/highly irregular intervals
protocols_moreinfo: For coral reef monitoring we use the GCRMN protocols, for fisheries monitoring we use FAO methods for small scale fisheries, for telemetry we are part of the Ocean tracking network

prog_name: Long- term Observation and Research of the East China Sea
prog_funders: Ministry of Science and Technology, Taiwan
key_inst: National Taiwan Ocean University, National Taiwan Normal University, Academia Sinica
type_moreinfo: Integrated observation program for physical, chemical, and biological oceanography, with focusing on pelagic systems.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: The program has two key phases.  1. Starting from 1989, the program called "Kuroshio Edge Exchange Processes, KEEP" only sampled the southern transect (so called, KEEP Key Line), with only chemical and physical data. Biological data were collected sporadically.  2. Starting from 2006, the program expands to cover the whole East China Sea. And the program shifted to focus on biology, while the chemical and physical variables are also collected.
freq_moreinfo: 1. The whole ECS were sampled once a year (summer time). In some years, spring was also sampled.  2. The southern transect (the  KEEP Key Line) was sampled almost monthly from April to Oct every year.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Fully restricted access- only data provider/program/network has access
dataaccess_moreinfo: The biological data can be accessed by contacting the PIs (data owners).
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: Lack of motivation. Nevertheless, the biological data can be accessed by contacting the PIs (data owners) through cooperation.
In_OBIS: No; none of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

type_moreinfo: Several long-term monitoring data sets on e.g. hydrography, phytoplankton and zooplankton abundance and biomass    Metadata on currently running programs:  https://sites.utu.fi/seili/wp-content/uploads/sites/62/2019/12/metadata-seuranta-aineistoille.pdf

Detailed metadata:  https://sites.utu.fi/seili/wp-content/uploads/sites/62/2019/12/metadata-seuranta-aineistoille.pdf
protocols_moreinfo: Zooplankton sampling and processing: HELCOM COMBINE   Standard practices are used in most programs

prog_name: Long-term monitoring program of soft sediments in the Bay of Morlaix
prog_funders: Sorbonne Université, Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Ifremer
funder_moreinfo: Part of the funding comes from the fact that the observation program is now included in the monitoring program of the European Water Framework Directive.
key_inst: Agence de l'Eau Loire-Bretagne
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_moreinfo: The long-term monitoring program of soft sediments in the Bay of Morlaix act as a raw data collector for 2 stations located in the Bay of Morlaix (English Channel). Part of this program is funded by the REBENT-DCE network which acts as a network of raw data collectors.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: For one site (i.e. rivière de Morlaix), some sampling dates are missing.
freq_moreinfo: Sampling frequency has changed over the monitoring program from 5x times per year to 2x per year.
protocols_moreinfo: Benthos sampling is performed using a Smith McIntyre grab; 10 replicates are collected at each date and the samples are sieved through a 1-mm circular mesh sieve on board and fixed with a 10% buffered formalin solution. The protocol has been the same since 1977.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: No, the raw data are publicly accessible/open.
dataaccess_restriction_level: NA
dataaccess_moreinfo: Biological data are also available via the Emodnet Biology portal.
In_OBIS: No; none of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_name: Long-term observation of phytoplankton in the Calvi Bay (Corsica, Western Mediterranean)
prog_funders: University of Liège (Belgium), STARESO (France), Territorial Collectivity of Corsica (Corsica),  French Water Agency PACA-Corsica (France)
funder_moreinfo: Long-term monitoring is submitted to success in obtaining new funding.
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: Sampling is conducted at the PHYTOCLY reference site, where sampling is performed either at the PHYTOCLY station (42°34.85'N, 08°43.71'E, water column depth 38 m), either closer to or from the shore. Distance between the PHYTOCLY station and the shore is about 300 m. Previous studies have shown strong similarity between surface total chlorophyll a and nitrate sampled simultaneously at the PHYTOCLY station and close to the coast.
duration_moreinfo: Subsurface phytoplankton was monitored during the winter-spring period between 1979 and 2005, with interruptions. Monitoring is continuous from 2006.
freq_moreinfo: Sampling is performed twice a week.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Fully restricted access- only data provider/program/network has access
dataaccess_moreinfo: Data will be publicly available after publication. Data can be shared by request in the framework of collaborations associating the data authors.
In_OBIS: No; none of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_url: We have 2 sites, This one is for reporting basking shark sightings and general info http://www.manxbaskingsharkwatch.org, our Facebook page is enormously popular, https://www.facebook.com/ManxBaskingSharkWatch
prog_network: We report our basking shark sightings to the Marine Conservation Society (UK)s Basking Shark Watch
prog_funders: Department of Environment, Food and Agriculture IOM Government (DEFA), Manx Lottery Trust (MLT), Department of Tourism IOM Government, Aberdeen University, Blackpool Aquarium, DONG Energy, Gough Ritchie Trust, Celton Manx, Sea Breezes Magazine, Steam-Packet Company, Tower Insurance Isle of Man, + small private donations.

type_moreinfo: Manx Basking Shark Watch has 2 aims. To scientifically study study basking sharks and to inform and enthuse the public about basking sharks.

freq_moreinfo: The public sightings section allows people to report their basking shark sightings (this is opportunistic). The satellite tagging program provides data up to every 20 seconds for the duration of the tagging of each basking sharks.

spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: Data was originally collected by 2 data providers in the 1950s and 1960s, by a third data provider in the 1980s and by a forth in the 1980s and 1990s. These were centrally and digitally archived and from this the current list of MarClim sites was selected after a resurvey of every original location. The current network is surveyed annually, although additional sites have been added since 2002.
protocols_moreinfo: SACFOR categorical scores for all 87 species, plus quantitative, replicated timed searches for trochids, 10 replicate 50cm x 50cm quadrat counts for limpets and replicate digital 5cm x 5cm photographs for barnacles at high, mid and lowshore at every site.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Restricted access- only data provider and another entity (e.g. contractor) have access to raw data
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: Institutional and funding body resctrictions on making data public due to potential for commercial gain.

prog_network: We collaborate with Museums Victoria but are independent. Our data has not yet been shared to major databases at this stage.
prog_funders: We receive no funding
funder_moreinfo: We receive no funding, but we do get assistance from Museums Victoria (preservatives, vials) and our specimens are lodged at Museums Victoria. We operate under our own collecting permits.
key_inst: Museums Victoria, Inverloch Shell Museum
type_moreinfo: Our group does surveys of intertidal invertebrates along the coast of Victoria, Australia and keeps records of species observed as well as collecting material for identification and research. Our members include significant local taxonomists who have published extensively, including Robert Burn (opisthobranchs), P. Mark O'Loughlin (echinoderms), David Staples (pycnogonids), Jan Watson (hydroids), Audrey Falconer (Staurozoa and Nemertea), Platon Vafiadis (gastropods), Don Cram (Cypraea),  Ken Bell (foraminifera), Philip Bock (Bryozoa), and a number of others who have not yet published extensively
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Our database has not yet been uploaded into Atlas of Living Australia but it will be one day.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: We cover the entire Victorian coastline to the extent possible. There is a huge gap on the 90 Mile Beach for obvious reasons.
duration_moreinfo: The MRG began formal sampling in 1981 in preparation for a book, Coastal Invertebrates of Victoria, An Atlas of Selected Species. Much fieldwork had been done previously and reported in the newsletter and this data is also included in our database. Formal collection of data though commenced in 1981.
freq_moreinfo: The MRG spends approximately 12 days in the field each year when tides are good. Different locations are chosen each year and we normally stay in an area and work locations around that area.
protocols_moreinfo: We have standards for collecting data which we are happy to provide to you if you wish.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: We are happy to share our data with anyone who asks.
data_aggregators_list: We will feed into Museums Victoria which will feed into Atlas of Living Australia and OBIS. All of our lodged specimens will already be in both databases.
In_OBIS: I don't know if the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_funders: none, monthly sampling financed out of my pocket, consumables financed by parasitising other projects
key_inst: Universidad de Los Lagos
type_moreinfo: The program is best characterised as long-term ecological research. Quantitative meiofaunal samples are collected monthly at three intertidal sites in the Seno Reloncaví in southern Chile. Granulometry, Sediment organic matter and Sediment photopigments are also measured. General oceanographic data comes from the university's oceanographic buoy located in the center of the Seno Reloncaví.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
protocols_moreinfo: Quantitative 50ml sediment samples.  Standardised extraction and mounting procedure

prog_name: MIKAROKA (International Observatory of Coastal Marine Biodiversity and Uses in Madagascar)
prog_funders: IRD (at the moment)
funder_moreinfo: At the moment, MIKAROKA is still a project. We'll know before the end of 2019 if this observatory is funded by IRD. As the amount of money is not sufficient (40k€ per year), we'll be obliged to find other supports
key_inst: Institut Halieutique et des Sciences Marines (IH.SM), Toliara, Madagascar & Centre National de recherche Océanographique (CNRO), Nosy Be, Madagascar
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Some examples:   For the fish component, surveys are intended to be done through eDNA. A 12S database will be built and shared with other scientists.  For the fishery component, tracking small fishermen will be performed with small GPS. GPS tracks will be automatically analyzed with a code that will be shared with other scientists.  There are amny other examples
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: will officially start in 2020 but we still have some series of data for coral, fish, and fishery from 2016 on in Toliara area (SW Madagascar)
freq_moreinfo: sampling frequency will vary between the different components (microbiome, corals, invertebrates, fish, birds, sharks, and fishery + a transversal component about maping benthic habitats)
protocols_moreinfo: Each component will use standard operating procedures in its field. It would be too long to detail here.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
In_OBIS: I don't know if the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS
vars_moreinfo: variables obtained when biological sampling is performed
AnythingElse: We will know if MIKAROKA is funded before the end of 2019. Surveys will start in 2020 for 2+3 years (evaluation at the end of year 2) + possibly 5. If everything goes well, it means a total of 10 years.

prog_name: Monitoring and Conservation of Black Sea Cetaceans
prog_funders: Mare Nostrum NGO
funder_moreinfo: The program is funded by the contribution of civil society through a found raising campaign and of course beside this through projects funded by private companies or ACCOBAMS.
key_inst: OBISSeamap; Medaces; ACCOBAMS; Black Sea Commission; MSFD; ECS
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_moreinfo: The program is dedicated to marine mammals and additional we are collecting birds and marine litter information. Was established in 2010 and from than we collect continuous information. Mainly is focused on Romanian Black Sea waters but second objective of Mare Nostrum is to develop basin wide projects (see CeNoBS project). Information collected are including strandings, bycatch, in situ observation using photo-id and line transect methods, awareness and dissemination, trainings, national monitoring network, scientific outputs, testing of conservation methods etc.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Raising capacity in Black Sea area for scientist is one of the main goals, in this direction there were developed a series of trainings (photo-identification, Distance sampling, aerial observation, monitoring network establishment, online database etc.)
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: The sampling location is composed by the shoreline of Romania and both Territorial Waters and Exclusive Economical Zone. From year to year the coverage could be wider or smaller in respect to the available budget.
freq_moreinfo: depending on the data collected the frecvency is different: eg. for stranding data we are collecting it monthly and when an alarm is on; for in situ could be from several days on sea to tens of days on sea/year.
protocols_moreinfo: We are using the ACCOBAMS guidelines
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Limited access- many entities have access to raw data (e.g. something is hindering it being fully open such as a moratorium or a secure login is needed)
dataaccess_moreinfo: some of the data are free but some are restricted due to publication reasons
In_OBIS: Yes; all of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_funders: Ministry of Fisheries and Marine Resources
funder_moreinfo: The National Marine Information and Research Centre (NatMIRC) is the research entity fully funded by the Ministry of Fisheries and Marine Resources to carry out monitoring and research activities in Namibia waters.
key_inst: Ministry of Fisheries and Marine Resources, Luderitz Monitoring program
type_moreinfo: Monitoring program that collects both biological (phytoplankton and zooplankton) and physical data (temperature, salinity, oxygen, nutrients, currents)
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: The 23 degree south transect with stations 2, 10-70 has been the primary line since 2000 but over the years a few lines have been added, namely at 20, 18, 26 and 28 degree south with same or fewer stations.
duration_moreinfo: The primary transect started sampling in 2000 and additional transects were added to the program over the subsequent years.
freq_moreinfo: For the primary transect, it was monthly for the first five years and then it become bimonthly over the years. Recently, the frequency had decrease to four times per year due to financial constraints.

type_moreinfo: The Moorea Coral Reef Long-term Ecological Research (MCR LTER) site was established by the National Science Foundation in 2004 as a model system to better understand factors that mediate coral community structure and function. A primary goal of the MCR LTER is to explore the effects of external drivers such as disturbance and global climate change on the resilience of coral reefs. This goal is achieved through long term-observations, experimental tests and models. Long-term trends in community structure are used to generate hypotheses that are tested experimentally. These empirical studies are then synthesized and modeled to gain novel insight into the responses of coral reefs to changing environments.

spatial_moreinfo: I am unclear of the scope of what you are asking for. Movebank supports data from anywhere in the world, including (1) avian, marine and terrestrial data (2) location data collected by loggers, transmitted by satellite and other wireless networks, or derived from other sensors and models (e.g. geolocation). A deployment site is not required, so many studies contain only sensor-based locations and will not have an explicitly defined deployment site.
duration_moreinfo: Movebank started in 2007 but stored sampled biological variables going back to at least the 1970s.

dataaccess_moreinfo: Level of access is controlled by the owner of each study in Movebank, meaning all options in 27-29 are possible. Read more at https://www.movebank.org/node/43. Owners may publicly and formally archive datasets in the Movebank Data Repository, which provides a DOI and CC0 data license. Read more at https://www.movebank.org/node/15294.
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: Please see note in #30. The level of access is controlled by the data owner and we support the use of Movebank regardless of whether it is public, legally restricted, etc.

vars_moreinfo: To be clear, Movebank stores data on the occurrence of fauna including marine mammals, birds, fish and turtles, as well as measurements from other animal-borne sensors. These data could be used to help understand abundance and distribution but we do not collect or store estimated values of abundance or distribution of these species.

MM_protocol_other: To be clear, we support data management using a standardized vocabulary and offer tools and support for quality control, but we do not oversee data collection practices.

prog_network: Arctic Shorebird Demographic Network; Interactions Working Group
prog_funders: Canadian Wildlife Service
key_inst: Polar Continental Shelf Program (Natural Resources Canada)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_moreinfo: The Arctic Shorebird Monitoring Program was initiated in response to widespread shorebird population declines noted on migration routes through southern Canada and the United States. Accurately estimating shorebird numbers during migration is difficult. More accurate estimates can be obtained from surveying the birds on their northern breeding grounds. The overall objective of the program is to produce population estimates for arctic-breeding shorebirds and then to monitor trends in their populations over time and investigate the causes of any population declines.      This project is the Arctic component of the larger Program for Regional and International Shorebird Monitoring (PRISM). Data collected from Arctic PRISM are used to:    1.	Generate population estimates for all arctic breeding shorebirds;  2.	Produce maps showing shorebird distribution and abundance across the North American arctic;  3.	Identify highest-quality habitats for each shorebird species;  4.	Provide shorebird densities and breeding ecology information at each survey site; and  5.	Assist local managers in meeting their conservation goals.    There are two main components to Arctic PRISM; Tier 1 “rapid” surveys that are conducted over large areas across the Arctic and are visited approximately every ten years, and Tier 2 “intensive” surveys that focus on smaller areas that are repeatedly surveyed in consecutive years.     Rapid surveys consist of surveying randomly selected 12ha plots and recording all birds seen and nests encountered. This will allow for the calculation of density estimates for birds on the arctic breeding grounds, which can then be extrapolated to develop population estimates.    The intensive surveys have two primary functions: 1) to develop a correction factor that can be applied to the results of the rapid surveys;  and 2) collect demographic information that may inform the causes of any observed population changes. This includes information such as rates of reproductive success (nest monitoring), adult and chick survival, site fidelity, and the locations of migratory routes and wintering and staging areas (through banding and deployment of tracking devices), among others.    The Nanuit Itillinga (formerly Polar Bear Pass) National Wildlife Area is a Tier 2 site where we have been collecting demographic information on shorebirds in recent years.  Surveys are planned to occur on a roughly 5-year on, 5-year off basis - with the most recent survey interval being conducted from 2015-2019.  Shorebird surveys at Nanuit Itillinga are planned to resume in ~2026.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: Preliminary reconnaissance and shorebird banding activities took place at the site from 2013-2014, and full intensive surveys (collection of demographic information, etc.) took place from 2015-19.  Intensive are anticipated to resume in 2026. All work took place within the vicinity of our camp location (approximate coordinate provided).
freq_moreinfo: Sampling is conducted daily during the shorebird nesting season (~15 June to 25 July), at approximately 5-year intervals.  The most recent sampling interval took place from 2015-2019. Surveys are expected to resume at the site in ~2026.
protocols_moreinfo: A variety of ecological data is collected at the site using the following sampling protocols:    - Arctic Program for Regional and International Shorebird Monitoring (Arctic PRISM)  - Arctic Shorebird Demographic Network  - Interactions Working Group

This is a relatively recent initiative and so our data has not yet been uploaded to these systems, but the process of making the data available is expected to occur over the next few years.

type_moreinfo: The National Biodiversity Data Centre is a national centre for the collection, collation, management, analysis and dissemination of data on Ireland’s biological diversity. This includes marine biodiversity data. The Data Centre has operated since 2007 and collects biodiversity data through a series of citizen science initiatives but also collated and stores data from external data collection programmes and also collates and stores historical data.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: We support data collection through training of volunteers, development of data visualisation products (mapping) and in some cases by hosting websites of external data collection programmes.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: Data collection is facilitated for Ireland, though individual data sets will vary in extent and distribution of data points
duration_moreinfo: The Data Centre started collecting records in 2007, individual data sets within the data centre will have varying time frames
freq_moreinfo: We average 1000-2000 marine data records anually at present, but with the launch of Explore Your Shore this is expected to grow. Data sets from external providers are updated periodically - every year or few years
protocols_moreinfo: We have a minimum standard for acceptance of species data. At a minimum records must have date; location; species name; recorder name. All data submitted via our citizen science portal is validated before being added to our biodiversity mapping system. Data from external providers is validated by those providers prior to submission.

dataaccess_moreinfo: All data collected under the Data Centre citizen science recording schemes is open access as per CC-BY. Data from external providers may be open access or restricted - whereby we map those data at a given resolution but to access raw data, you must contact the data provider.

prog_name: National Observatory System: Mammals as Ocean Samplers
prog_funders: CNRS, French Polar Institute (IPEV), Centre National d'Etudes Spatiales (CNES)
key_inst: Zone Atelier Antarctique,  Observatoire Aquitain des Sciences de l'Univers, MEOP (www.meop.net); IMOS,  EuroGOOS, JCOMMOPS
type_moreinfo: Using Biologging and biotelemetry we are collecting long term foraging data (tracks, diving,...) of Antarctic seals (Elephant seals and Weddell seals) along biological information (prey encouters, bioluminescence...) along biogechemical information (Chl-a concentration, dissolved oxygen) and physical oceanographic profiles (temperture, salinity) at high frequency.  Furthermore information on wind speed and sea-states are derivated form the processing of accoustic and acceleration signals. On land weaning mass, stable isotopes signatures are collected on an annual basis to assess the ecological consequences of inter-annual-decadal changes of at-sea  environnental conditions. This  observatory first started in 2004, and was first labelled National Observatory in 2011, renewed in 2015 and 2019.  The SNO was extended to Argentina in 2018 (Elephant seals from Valdez Peninsula, Coll. CONICET, UBA, WCS) and to hooded seals in 2017 (coll. DFO-Canada)
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Loggers co-developpement and data processing.  As part of these program new loggers were developped (CTD-Fluo and CTD-Oxygen) tags for seals and sea turtles in collaboration with SMRU,  Active acoustic (µ-sonar in collaboration with M. Johnson SMRU)...  Data processing: light attenuation to assess chl-a concentration/biomass,  on-board processing of collected data...
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: First tag deployment in 2003, First collection of elecological information along oceanographic ones in 2004.

Oceanographic parameter are made freely available through the MEOP portal.

vars_moreinfo: The High Frequency CTD data allows to estimate heat fluxes and vertical advection at submesoscale.  Sea state (from acoustic measurements : wind speed and acceleration measurment: wave frequency and amplitude
MM_methods_other: Count on the beaches during the breeding season, or on the sea-ice (weddell seals and Hooded seals)

prog_name: No dedicated observing network - but different locally based projects to monitor and mitigate threats to cetaceans
prog_url: https://wwf.panda.org/knowledge_hub/endangered_species/cetaceans/   (note that this will soon include a map overview of all WWF cetacean work
prog_funders: WWF
key_inst: At a global level, WWF is working with the IUCN Marine Mammal Protected Areas Task Force, the International Whaling Commission, the Global Ghost Gear Initiative, the Convention on Migratory Species, and many more.  On a local level there are many partnerships with government and others.
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: Different WWF offices around the globe are involved directly in (collaborative) research projects to collect data.  On a global level, WWF is also collaborating with partners to compile data into useful overviews.  One such example is a collaboration between WWF and the IUCN Marine Mammal Protected Areas Task force to conduct a geospatial analysis of the overlap between vessel traffic and Important Marine Mammal Areas (IMMAs - https://www.marinemammalhabitat.org/activities/immas/).
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: We do not have any positional data/spatial information to share at the global level at this time.  We will circulate this request to WWF offices involved in cetacean research to see if they would like to contribute.

prog_name: NOAA NEFSC Ships of Opportunity Program Continuous Plankton Recorder Survey
prog_funders: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
funder_moreinfo: Funding and operations ceased in 2013. This is not a currently active program.
key_inst: Global Alliance of Continuous Plankton Recorder Surveys (GACS)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: This program was initially started and operated by the Edinburgh Oceanographic Laboratory (this group was the predecessor to the current Plymouth Marine Biological Association CPR Survey which still operates a number of similar surveys globally). NOAA assumed operational control/support of the sampling in U.S. waters starting in 1974. NOAA remains the caretaker of the pre-NOAA data. NOAA Support ended in 2013. Plymouth MBA briefly resumed the sampling 2014-2017 but also discontinued due to a lack of funding support.
protocols_moreinfo: This program used the standard continuous plankton recorder methods and gear used by other CPR programs globally including the Global Alliance of Continuous Plankton Recorder Surveys and the Plymouth MBA CPR Survey.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.

dataaccess_moreinfo: The data are not currently be served on the web in raw form (the prior system on which it was served is no longer operating) but this data is still available upon request without any restrictions.
data_aggregators_list: Global Alliance of CPR Surveys, NOAA COPEPOD Global Plankton Database.

prog_funders: The OCS Project is primarily funded by the NOAA OAR CPO Ocean Observing and Monitoring Division. Some partners are funded by other national and international agencies.

CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: The OCS program encourages broad use of the data and welcomes collaboration.  Groups are welcome to partner with us to deploy sensors on OCS moorings, provided that (1) the sensor/system does not impact the primary measurements, nor impact the performance of the mooring, and that (2) all data are made freely available in a timely way. Visit our data pages, and contact us to learn more.

spatial_moreinfo: KEO nominal position is 32.3N 144.6E; Papa nominal position is 50N, 145W;  ARC is now discontinued.
duration_moreinfo: KEO began in June 2004;  Station Papa OCS mooring begain in June 2007
freq_moreinfo: The network carries physical and BGC observations at this point, KEO has had Jie Yang's (UW APL) Passive Listening Device from 2018-2019. She also has had a PAL at Station Papa since 2010. A Noise Reference Station Mooring (Bob Dziak) was deployed next to the OCS mooring since Jan 2015.

prog_name: Northeast U.S. Shelf Long Term Ecological Research
prog_funders: National Science Foundation
key_inst: Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, University of Massachusetts Dartmouth, University of Rhode Island, Wellesley College, NOAA Northeast Fisheries Science Center
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: This question forcing one year is very awkard to answer and does not represent the program well.   NES-LTER formally started in 2017 with NSF funding; importantly, however, many variables were measured historically at the NES-LTER study sites. For example, phytoplankton observations at MVCO started in 2003 and NEFSC surveys for zooplankton and fish have been on-going since the 1960s and 1970s
freq_moreinfo: The NES-LTER network takes advantage of a wide range of sampling strategies so specifying one biological sampling frequency is very artificial. We have observations at sub-daily scales at ocean observatories (MVCO and OOI Pioneer), ~monthly boat trips for more sampling at MVCO, quarterly cruises across the shelf between MVCO and OOI Pioneer, and ~quarterly NOAA ECOMON regional surveys.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: No, the raw data are publicly accessible/open.
dataaccess_restriction_level: NA
dataaccess_moreinfo: We are in the process of adding access to more data types through EDI.

prog_name: Ocean Biogeographic Information System Spatial Ecological Analysis of Megavertebrate Populations
prog_funders: None
funder_moreinfo: Currently no funding for the entire project but OBIS-SEAMAP has sub projects one of which is  sub-contracted by US Navy / HDR Inc. now.  In the past, OBIS-SEAMAP was funded by Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, National Science Foundation, National Oceanographic Partnership Program and Naval Postgraduate School
key_inst: ACCOBAMS & WDCS Initiative, Happywhale (happywhale.com), Satellite Tracking and Analysis Tool (http://www.seaturtle.org/stat/), US Navy
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_moreinfo: We collect visual sightings, telemetry data, passive acoustic detections. We also produce/collect estimated density (or other indicators) of marine mammals. Our lab leads a similar project called Migratory Connectivity in the Ocean (MiCO, https://mico.eco) where we produce connectivity (nodes, corridors and use areas) of marine mammals, seabirds, sea turtles and fish.
spatial_options: NA
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Limited access- many entities have access to raw data (e.g. something is hindering it being fully open such as a moratorium or a secure login is needed)
dataaccess_moreinfo: This issue is not as easy as "Everyone can access data" or "Only logged-in uses can access data". Basically, OBIS-SEAMAP data are publicly available but those include data in "standard" format. We collect all sort of "additional" attributes whose availability differs provider by provider. Also, we collect telemetry data from seaturtle.org and their "raw" data are not publicly available upon the agreement with seaturtle.org but the aggregated data are available to the public.
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: Some researchers do not like to release the data while they are doing their own research/projects. Other researchers do not feel comfortable in releasing sensitive attributes such as perpendicular distance to sighted animals.
In_OBIS: Yes; more than half but not all of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_network: Ocean Biogeographic Information System (OBIS), IODE Associate Data Unit (ADU)
prog_funders: Canadian Foundation for Innovation (CFI),Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC), Research Nova Scotia (RNS), Dalhousie University, Fisheries and Oceans Canada (DFO), In Kind from multiple International Partners
key_inst: Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission (IOC), International Oceanographic Data and Information Exchange (IODE), Global Ocean Observing System (GOOS), Ocean Biogeographic Information System (OBIS), Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS), the Acoustic Tracking Array Platform (ATAP), European Tracking Network (ETN), US Integrated Ocean Observing System / Animal Telemetry Network (IOOS ATN), Great Lakes Acoustic Telemetry Observation System (GLATOS), Mid-Atlantic Acoustic Telemetry Observation System (MATOS), FACT Network, Migramar Network, Federal University of Rio Grand (FURG), Group on Earth Observations (GEO) / Blue Planet (BP), European Marine Observation and Data Network (EMODNet), Ocean Data and Information System Catalogue (ODISCat)
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: The OTN has extensively trained academic and technical personnel nationally and internationally  to participate in the ocean science sector. Personnel trained by the OTN have also spun out four companies, and one Environmental NGO that are providing technologies and services for the ocean science sector. The knowledge/technology generated by our researchers and the spin-offs are helping to inform policy development and management of ocean resources, as well as boosting the Canadian economy.     OTN has developed world class capabilities for ocean monitoring. This includes establishing a global network for monitoring the movements and survival of marine animals using electronic telemetry, the establishment of Canada’s most experienced operational glider (marine autonomous vehicle) fleet which operates out of the Centre for Ocean Ventures and Enterprise (COVE), and an internationally certified data system for animal telemetry data (Associate Data Unit of UNESCO’s Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission’s International Oceanographic Information and Data Exchange (ADU-IODE); Tier II node for the Ocean Biogeographic Information System). We also have equipment and expertise in the use of Remotely Operated Vehicles, and are developing capabilities for side-scan sonar. This equipment and expertise will be used in service of researchers internationally.     OTN has also undertaken several development projects in association with industry to create new technologies that serve the mission of the OTN while also providing sales to the participating companies. These have included the development of new acoustic receiver technologies (in association with InnovaSea (formerly Vemco), and the addition of acoustic receiver capacity to the MetOcean Lagrangian Surface Drifters. OTN is participating as a partner in applications for new technology development to the Ocean Super Cluster.     OTN also transfers its technology and knowledge to industry by using its assets to assist in sustainable development of the ocean by helping  in the conduct of environmental impact assessments.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: NOTE: Just because satellite data does NOT imply global coverage.
duration_moreinfo: OTN started sampling 2008 but currently hold data from DFO  starting 2002.  Other partners and  data rescues may include earlier sampling as well.
freq_moreinfo: ~4,000 receivers on the ocean/sea/lake floors collecting pings from passing tagged aquatic animal.  Slocam and wave gliders with ocean sensors and acoustic receivers.
protocols_moreinfo: will eventually be posting SOPs to OBPS (Ocean Best Practices System).

freq_moreinfo: The sediment traps (500, 1500, 3200 m depths) sample continuously, with a nominal bimonthly sampling interval. The upward looking ADCP (300m depth) samples 0-300m currents continuously at 15 min intervals. The MicroCAT ODO (500m depth) samples T,S,O at 15 min intervals. The MicroCAT (4000m depth) samples T, S at 30 sec intervals

prog_name: On the tracks of great pelagic marine animals (whales, dolphins, sea turtles, swordfish and tunas)
prog_funders: Currently self-funded through KYMA sea conservation & research
key_inst: As it is a new programme starting in 2020 we don't have a network of affilitates yet
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Currently, the program is organized as citizen science programme. We are open to extend it as such that it will provide more information on the capacity development for ocean observing.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: The programme will start in June 2020 but is based on survey work conducted between 2016-2019 by the same PI
freq_moreinfo: The sampling takes part in two separate survey periods: one in June and July and one in September. During these periods the sampling frequency is daily.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: No, the raw data are publicly accessible/open.
dataaccess_restriction_level: NA
In_OBIS: Yes; more than half but not all of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS
vars_moreinfo: We will also collect systematic data on floating macroplastic at the sea surface
alldataproviders: Raw data collector/provider (observatory/site/program collects data) NA

prog_funders: ORCA funds this through charitable donations from members and corporate bodies
key_inst: ORCA runs this programme but the data is utilised by other organisations, networks and institutions upon request
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_moreinfo: ORCA trains up members of the public to become Marine mammal Surveyors who then go out on platforms of opportunity (primarily ferry and cruise ships) across the globe to collect scientific data on marine mammals
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: As platforms of opportunity are ustilised for data collection it is not easy to represent the sites sampled in the formats provided above. However, we have provided a snapshot of these.  Ferry surveys - occur once or twice per month, crossing the same area each time.  Cruise surveys - these are more adhoc, taking place a various number of times per year across huge geographical areas - cover Atlantic, Pacific, Arctic and Southern Oceans, and Mediterranean Sea
duration_moreinfo: This network grows each year with new routes/sites sampled and increased geographical coverage. It is continuing to grow in terms of geographical coverage, number of surveys and survey season extension
freq_moreinfo: Ferry surveys - once or twice a month, between March to November each year  Cruise surveys - at least two per month year round, but sites vary throughout the year and between years
protocols_moreinfo: ORCA distance sampling, fixed-line transect surveying protocol & ORCA observation scientific protocol
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: ORCA needs to provide permission for data requests due to the need to ensure charitable objectives are upheld
In_OBIS: No; none of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS
vars_moreinfo: We also collect information on weather conditions: precipitation, glare, visibility
MM_vars_age: Age (year, age class, life history stage)
alldataproviders: NA Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)

prog_name: Ore estuary (Orefjarden), Umea Marine Sciences Centre (LTER) - Sweden
prog_funders: The Swedish Agency for Water and Marine Management, Umeå University, County boards
key_inst: The Swedish Environmental Protection Agency, The Swedish Agricultural University, The Swedish Coast Guard
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: In the short term part of the Swedish environmental monitoring program for status assessment . In the long term long ecological time series for environmental and climate research.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Mainly within the LTER network, Helsinki commission for the Baltic Sea (Helcom) and International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES).
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: The Baltic Sea, north western Bothnian Sea, Sweden
duration_moreinfo: Data with less stringent quality assurance available since 1978.
freq_moreinfo: Vary between 24 and 10 times per year. From year 2000  two stations in the same water body are sampled 10 times per year.
protocols_moreinfo: Standard operating procedures in general following the Helcom Combine guidelines are used during the whole period declared. The laboratory has been accredited since 2006.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: No, the raw data are publicly accessible/open.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: The national data host web site is in Swedish, but support in English can be arranged on request. Primary data is also archived at Umeå Marine Sciennces Center data base dBotnia.
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: Lack of commision as datahost and thereby funding development and support.
data_aggregators_list: The Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI, national data host)

prog_funders: NOAA Fisheries
key_inst: Scripps Institution of Oceanography Whale Acoustics Lab
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: PIPAN is a network of passive acoustic recording sites in US waters of the central and western Pacific designed to monitor ambient and anthropoegnic sounds, including those produced by marine mammals. We primarily use the data to assess cetacean occurrence, seaosnality, and relative abundance, and develop soundscape metrics for comparison across the network and with other networks along the US east and west coasts.  PIPAN dat is collected with High-Frequency Acoustic Recording Packages sampling at 200 kHz, and consists of 5 sites monitored for more than ad ecade, as well as other sites moitored fr shorter periods or perdiocually.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: Various sites have been samples for different durations.  Some sites have data gaps due to instrument issues.
freq_moreinfo: Acoustic data are generlly collected on a duty-cycle, 5 minutes sampling, 1-30 minutes off.  Most recent datsets are sampled continuously.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: The data volume is too large (>200TB) for serving on public websites such that dat arequestors must provide harddrives (or web-accessible cloud storage) for the data arequested.

prog_name: Partnership for the Intediscplinary Study of Coastal OCeans
prog_abbrev: PISCO (Partnership for the Intediscplinary Study of Coastal OCeans)
prog_network: The Oregon State University node of PISCO
prog_funders: PISCO (Partnership for the Intediscplinary Study of Coastal Oceans), funded primarily through the David and Lucille Packard Foundation I believe
key_inst: http://www.piscoweb.org/people-2
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: Oregon State's PISCO node has 20 years of data on intertidal algae and other macrophyte abundances. They also have a much smaller intertidal program that from 2001-2004 collected some limited subtidal surveys focused on kelp forest and rocky reef habitat. That subtidal work is not ongoing.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: For more information contact Bruce Menge
duration_moreinfo: The subtidal work was only conducted from ~2001-2004, whereas the subtidal work has been collected fairly consistently since the late 1990s. For more details ask Bruce Menge. I know mostly about the subtidal work, so I have probably missed important details about the intertidal work.
freq_moreinfo: Intertidal data is collected much more frequently than subtidal. The subtidal data was collected once every 1-2 years, whereas many intertidal sites are visited at least monthly.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Limited access- many entities have access to raw data (e.g. something is hindering it being fully open such as a moratorium or a secure login is needed)
dataaccess_moreinfo: Many of the datasets are available freely online at DataOne, but they are often not updated frequently and thus may be many years behind. You may need to email PISCO PIs for more recent information
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: They are working to make it public, it just takes time to get the data cleaned and up on Data One.
In_OBIS: I don't know if the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS
