prog_network: All observing programs working towards specific obligations as State Party to biodiversity related MEAs like the Convention on Biological Diversity, Ramsar Convention
prog_funders: Government of Kiribati, bilateral funding supports like GIZ MACBIO regional project
key_inst: 1. SPREP; 2. CBD; 3. Ramsar Convention; 4. GIZ MACBIO Project
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: Most of the observation program we are currently pursuing at the country level are driven in part, to collect data on the atolls environment, island biodiversity, and other environment related data like wastes and pollution, etc
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: This is basically to meet environment portfolio at the national level, as well as to collect data that would assist with national reporting to various environment related Multi Environment Agreements like the CBD, Montreal Protocols, etc, which Government of Kiribati is STATE PARTY to
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
freq_moreinfo: Currently, environment spatial planning is recently introduced to MELAD ECD. Data are just being compiled and collected as part of the EMIS - Environment Management Information System Database from 2018 to data
protocols_moreinfo: Would send such information once i got it from our key Environment Spatial Planning consultant who is currently on leave. He is being contracted to assist ECD, MELAD as part of the GOK component under the regional MACBIO Project that Kiribati is also part of
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: Currently, we are also reviewing our Environment Act (as amended 2007) this year, to enhance data access including data collection, storage, and sharing with the Office of Attorney General to identify and address data gaps in Kiribati (data relating to atolls environment)
data_aggregators_list: will send full information on this answer via same email stated

AnythingElse: This is an important area that i would like to follow up further on. In Kiribati, MELAD ECD is the national focal point for biodiversity related conventions like CBD; World Heritage; Ramsar Convention. MELAD ECD also has biodiversity conservation and wildlife conservation Programs as part of the environment portfolio/mandates. Hence thank you for this opportunity and would love to hear more about the technical assistance/resources/support that you may offer which we may be interested to explore with you. Many thanks once more!

spatial_moreinfo: The plankton has been sampled monthly (with some breaks) since 1969 at a single site off the Northumberland coast 55 degrees 07'N 1 degree 20'W in water of 54m depth. WP2 (200um) WP3 (1mm) and a Plymouth 200 (63um) mesh nets are used.
protocols_moreinfo: Plymouth 200 (63um mesh)  WP2 (200um mesh)  WP3 (1mm mesh) all have been used routinely. Plankton and microzooplankton sampling will commence in 2020

prog_funders: Sorbonne Université
funder_moreinfo: The series was funded as part of many research projects (too many to list here). The only long term funding support is from Sorbonne Université (formerly Université Pierre et Marie Curie)
key_inst: Sorbonne Université, RESOMAR, IR-ILICO
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: The program comprises the collection of plankton using three nets, the series of which started at different dates:  1966-active: Juday-Bogorov, 330µm  1975-active: Regent Net, 680µm  1995-active: WP2 net, 200µm
freq_moreinfo: Data collection and frequency is different depending on the nets:  J-B: daily sampling every other week, data pooled and released as one point every other week  Régent: daily sampling, data pooled and released weekly  WP2: daily sampling initially then pooled weekly, now sampled weekly.  => overall, the mode of the frequency is weekly.
protocols_moreinfo: Sampling protocol is well defined but does not adhere to any international standards (the series pre-date the establishment of such standards).  Analysis is now carried out with the ZooScan instrument, following well defined protocols.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: No, the raw data are publicly accessible/open.
dataaccess_restriction_level: NA
dataaccess_moreinfo: A proposal has been submitted to EMODnet biology to provide access to the three series.
data_aggregators_list: EMODnet Biology/EurOBIS (and therefore OBIS and GBIF)
In_OBIS: Yes; less than half of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS
vars_moreinfo: Those variables are collected as part of the SOMLIT observation network http://somlit.epoc.u-bordeaux1.fr/fr/ at the same site and frequency but are not directly part of RadeZOO.
AnythingElse: An effort is ongoing to federate the series of zooplankton observation in France into a network (similar to the network PHYTOBS, currently registered in your list). It should take place over the next 4 years (the next evaluation to officialise such networks is in 4 years).

prog_name: Republic of ireland  Phytoplankton National Monitoring Programme
prog_funders: Public funded
key_inst: FSAI (Food Safety Authority of Ireland) www.fsai.ie  ; SFPA (Sea Fisheries Protection Agency) www.sfpa.ie ; ICES WGPME (Working Group in Phytoplankton and Microbial Ecology) www.ices.dk; EURLMB (European Union Reference Laboratory Marine Biotoxins) https://ec.europa.eu/ ; IGMETS (International Group for Marine Ecological Time Series) www.igmets.net ; Primrose project ; IPI International Phytoplankton Intercomparison programme) www.iphyi.org ; Oceanteacher IODE http://classroom.oceanteacher.org/
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_Directory: Directory of programs/networks/observatories (the program provides information on observing networks/programs)
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Capacity development:  Taxonomy: Building high resolution microscopy suite including SEM   Developing Molecular tools to confirm identification through gene probes.   Culture unit: Building an ecologically important culture collection of marine protists.  Development of Biovolume measurements in the National Monitoring Programme as proxy for biomass an Carbon content measurements.  Manage/organise International Phytoplankton Intercomparison scheme in association with IOC of UNESCO and IODE (Oceanteacher), as the only international programme to test phytoplankton taxonomists  globally and certifying their taxonomic proficiency.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: The phytoplankton monitoring programme commenced a year after the rat bioassay in 1985 and in its earlier version, the main interest was on high biomass samples. It was predicated in the belief that many cells were needed in a sample to have a toxic event. The data recorded was limited to a few species only per sample and the information contained about the sample was very limited. This continued until 1995 when the first phytoplankton database was developed by the Marine Institute and was named ‘Fitobase’. Fitobase was the first Access database and it was a definite improvement from the previous system which included a standardized Phytoplankton species list and there was no limit to the amount of species entered per sample, also some information about the sample was included. All the previous data from 1985 to 1995 was transferred to this new database.     In 2002, the new Harmful Algal Base (HABs) database which has been developed in-house, was launched and it has been running for the last fifteen year until 2018, when it was decommissioned to provide space to our new improved current system HABS2. This system is a modern database developed as an online platform which allows us to publish Phytoplankton results close to real-time and fully open to the public. The phytoplankton results can be plotted over a timeline to show trends of the main toxic species and these can be compared against toxin results for the same area. These figures can give near real time information and act as an early warning system to the shellfish industry of an impending toxic event. This system has been developed fully from scratch and it is fully accredited to ISO standard 17025.
freq_moreinfo: Sampling frequency is weekly. If an event occur, we can increase frequency to 2 x week or more if required but the minimum frequency is weekly all year around.
protocols_moreinfo: We are accredited to ISO17025 and we follow the best fit for purpose method for Phytoplankton analysis. This is the Utermohl method based on 25 ml samples.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: Toxic species data is publicly available in https://webapps.marine.ie/HABs/ but the full data set needs to be asked for formally through the Data Management team in the Marine Institute through our website www.marine.ie
In_OBIS: No; none of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_name: SCAR Southern Ocean Continuous Plankton Recorder Survey
prog_funders: Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR); Australian Antarctic Division (AAD) of the Department of Environment; National Institute of Polar Research (NIPR), Tokyo; National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research (NIWA, New Zealand; Alfred Wegener Institute (AWI), Germany; Antarctic Marine Living Resources programme (NOAA US-AMLR), USA; Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute (AARI), Russia; Programa Antartico Brasileiro (PROANTAR), Brazil; Instituto Antartico Chileno (INACH), Chile; Department of Environmental Affairs (DEA), South Africa; Institut polaire francais - Paul-Emile Victor (IPEV) and Universite Pierre-et-Marie-Curie (UPMC), France.
key_inst: GACS, CCAMLR, SOOS, Atlas of Living Australia, IMOS, OBIS, GBIF
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: The SO-CPR database is a SCAR Business Product, primary held at the Australian Antarctic Data Centre as well as by survey partners, and distributed to GACS, IMOS, SOOS, GBIF, OBIS, biodiversity.aq, Atlas of Living Australia plus others
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: Area, south of the Sub-Antarctic Front to the Antarctic continent, and circumpolar. Active since 1991. Identifying zooplankton to species level where possible and to developmental stages for Antarctic krill and other euphausiids.
freq_moreinfo: CPRs are deployed on available Antarctic shipping (research vessels, supply vessels, fishing vessels) whenever possible, primarily from early spring to late March.  Some year round sampling occurs.  We aim average 3000 samples per year at 5 nautical mile resolution.  The individual samples are sub-daily.
protocols_moreinfo: SO-CPR has a standardised field and laboratory protocol set in a manual, supported by regular data quality and standardisation workshops.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: Are the data publicly available - Yes and No.  Presence/absence data are freely available from a number of sites.  The actual raw quantitative data needs to be requested so that there is opportunity to instructs users on how to use the data, how the data are acquired, and the limitations of the data.  Some people assume too much.  Plus, there are requirements for the proper citation and acknowledgement of the data and SO-CPR.
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: We require proper citation and acknowledgement
data_aggregators_list: AADC, GACS, SCAR biodiversity.aq, OBIS, GBIF, IMOS, Atlas of Living Australia
In_OBIS: Yes; all of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS
Zooplankton_diversity_aggregate: Network aggregates data for this variable
Zooplankton_diversity_dataproduct: Data products from this variable are developed by the network
Zooplankton_diversity_datause: Network uses data for this variable
vars_moreinfo: Multiple underway marine and climatic environmental variables are usually collected at the same time by ships' systems, along with GPS and can be tied to the biological data.  The data set itself does not include the environmental data.
AnythingElse: The dataset is quite enormous and there is a considering amount of supporting information that is available of request. We are finishing a report to SCAR on achievements the first 25+ years of the SO-CPR based on ~60 reviewed publications and theses.  We hope to make the report available ASAP.  A publication list is available.
alldataproviders: Raw data collector/provider (observatory/site/program collects data) Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)

prog_funders: BirdLife International, The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB), Darwin Plus (The Overseas Territories Environment and Climate Fund), EU-BEST, European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme, Global Ocean Biodiversity Initiative (GOBI), International Climate Initiative (IKI) of the German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, and Nuclear Safety (BMU), Wallace Research Foundation, Lenfest Ocean Program, AV Jensen Foundation, Packard Foundation, The Pew Charitable Trusts, Darwin Initiative, Prince Albert II of Monaco Foundation.
funder_moreinfo: Various funders and projects have contributed to development and maintenance of the database, and data analyses undertaken by BirdLife. The data are contributed by researchers worldwide, whose funding sources are not covered here.
key_inst: A list of data contributors can be found at http://seabirdtracking.org/mapper/about.php.
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_moreinfo: The Seabird Tracking Database is a repository for researchers to store seabird tracking data and make it available for others to request, facilitating collaborations. Ownership of the data is retained by the contributors, who can give permission for others to access their data. A major use of the data is for conservation – BirdLife scientists undertake large-scale analyses using multiple datasets to inform our global seabird conservation work.
spatial_options: NA
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: Anyone can request a user account and then request data from the Seabird Tracking Database. Some datasets are pre-approved for all requests, but in many cases the data owners have to check and approve the request. There are different levels of pre-approvals depending on the data owners’ preferences.
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: The datasets we hold are owned by the contributors rather than BirdLife International, so it is not our decision on whether to make them publicly accessible. The decision on whether to make the data available (i.e. pre-approved for all requests) is made by the data owners for each of their datasets. The Seabird Tracking Database serves as a central store for seabird tracking data from around the world and aims to support and facilitate collaboration between the scientific community.
data_aggregators_list: The Seabird Tracking Database is a data aggregator.

type_moreinfo: SeagrassNet is an expanding, worldwide ecological monitoring program that investigates and documents the status of seagrass resources and the threats to this important and imperilled marine ecosystem. The program started in 2001 in the Western Pacific and now includes 137 sites in 35 countries with a global monitoring protocol and web-based data reporting system. Our ultimate aim is to preserve the valuable seagrass ecosystem by increasing scientific knowledge and public awareness of this threatened coastal resource.

prog_funders: Alfred-Wegener Institute for Polar and Marine Research, Australian Antarctic Division, Applied Physics Lab University of Washington, ENSTA Bretagne, Brest, France & LabSTICC CNRS UMR, COPAS Sur-Austral Center, Chile; CEAZA Research Center, Coquimbo, Chile & Woods Hole Oceanographic institute, Centre for Research into Ecological and Environmental Modelling University of St Andrews,Scripps Institution of Oceanography University of California San Diego, International Whaling Commission Southern Ocean Research Partnership
funder_moreinfo: Funding for PI and student engagement is largely in-kind support from PI's home institutions. Funding for data collection and analysis is mostly via national research programs. Coordination, infrastructure and analysis is funded via in-kind contributions from members as well as grants from International Whaling Commission's Southern Ocean Research Partnership (IWC-SORP).
key_inst: Acoustic Trends Working Group; Southern Ocean Observing System (SOOS) and IWC-SORP
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_moreinfo: The SOHN is a federated network of national long-term passive acoustic recording sites in the southern ocean. See Opzeeland, I. Van et al. (2013) ‘Towards collective circum-Antarctic passive acoustic monitoring: The Southern Ocean Hydrophone Network (SOHN)’, Polarforschung, 83(2), pp. 47–61.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: See Opzeeland, I. Van et al. (2013) ‘Towards collective circum-Antarctic passive acoustic monitoring: The Southern Ocean Hydrophone Network (SOHN)’, Polarforschung, 83(2), pp. 47–61.
duration_moreinfo: Ad-hoc long-term passive acoustic data collection in the Antarctic began in 2001. The IWC-SORP Acoustic Trends Working Group formed in 2009, and the Southern Ocean Hydrophone Network commenced in 2013. For more details see: Opzeeland, I. Van et al. (2013) ‘Towards collective circum-Antarctic passive acoustic monitoring: The Southern Ocean Hydrophone Network (SOHN)’, Polarforschung, 83(2), pp. 47–61.
freq_moreinfo: Many sites record passive acoustic data continuously, and nearly all sites record some acoustic data every hour.
protocols_moreinfo: Recommendations for data collection provided in:  Opzeeland, I. Van et al. (2013) ‘Towards collective circum-Antarctic passive acoustic monitoring: The Southern Ocean Hydrophone Network (SOHN)’, Polarforschung, 83(2), pp. 47–61.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: Access to data is by request due to large data volumes (e.g. 1-2 TB/year).
In_OBIS: Yes; less than half of the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

prog_funders: Natural Environment Research Council NERC-UK
funder_moreinfo: NERC-UK provided seed money for the network, but all institutes involved supplied time, data and analysis to the project and therefore funds in kind. IMOS started before this project and continue to provide acoustic data (I see it is already added to your list). MESOPP (EU funded project) provided Australian, French and UK data from a single portal.
key_inst: Austrailian Antarctic Division (Australia), Commenwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO, Australia), Institut de Recherche pour le deveoppement (IRD, France), Institute of Marine Research (IMR, Norway), Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS, Australia), National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research (NIWA, New Zealand), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Fisheries Service (USA)
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_moreinfo: Network of data collectors with a view to harmonising data processing to provide consistent products. This was later completed by France, UK and Australia under the EU funded project MESOPP  IMOS was a framework that we used to try and pull this together
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: I would consider the network latent - requiring funds to progress to the next level to provide data. I would consider that all groups maintain interest if suitable infrastructure was developed to facilitate transfer
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: The sampling locations are cruise tracks. With data collected at fine resolution. None of your above formats work. Images have been sent to satterthwaite. I have provided the cruise tracks that BAS has completed over the years. Other tracks are available from IMOS and MESOPP
freq_moreinfo: Research and fishing vessels continue to collect calibrated acoustic data in the Southern Ocean. However, my response above refers to BAS' contribution - which continues to collect at least annual cruises in the South Atlantic sector of the Southern Ocean. IMOS continues to provide from the Pacific sector.
protocols_moreinfo: Acoustic data are calibrated, and collected with (semi) consistent settings.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Limited access- many entities have access to raw data (e.g. something is hindering it being fully open such as a moratorium or a secure login is needed)
dataaccess_moreinfo: Some raw data is open access and DOI'ed, some is limited access for a set time period. The data is quite large and at the moment infrastructure, high speed access and appropriate metadata probably limits it.
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: Mixture or resource, appropriate metadata, appropriate infrastructure, QCing, agreed processing framework
In_OBIS: I don't know if the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Development of automated detectors for passive acoustic monitoring of whales; training of doctoral students and postdoctoral fellows in passive acoustic monitoring approaches.    We are an international group that collects, shares and collaboratively analyses passvie acoustic data from the Southern Hemisphere and the Southern Ocean to monitor populations of blue and fin whales.

funder_moreinfo: It is partly funded by NAM for the ecological monitoring of the gas drilling areas in the eastern Wadden Sea.
key_inst: NWO
type_moreinfo: SIBES  -Synoptic Intertidal Benthic Survey- is a monitoring scheme for sampling intertidal macrofauna across the Dutch Wadden Sea. It is partly funded by NAM for the ecological monitoring of the gas drilling areas in the eastern Wadden Sea.  SIBES uses a gridded sampling design that encompasses the entire Dutch Wadden Sea, with a combination of sample points taken at 500m intervals, and additional random sample points. Thus, it maximises effectiveness at minimal costs.

spatial_moreinfo: This is a monitoring program focusing on the areas around the Italina research Station in Terra Nova Bay. We have just got funds to expand the sampling area at other sites in the Ross Sea but these have not been defined yet
duration_moreinfo: Within this monitoring program sampling was not done for all years for all activities but we're trying to make it permanent.
protocols_moreinfo: All will be published. The first step which are the photogrammetric techniques are already available. Have a look here:  Piazza, P., Cummings, V. J., Lohrer, D. M., Marini, S., Marriott, P., Menna, F., ... & Schiaparelli, S. (2018). Divers-operated underwater photogrammetry: applications in the study of Antarctic benthos. International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences, 42(2), 885-892.  Piazza, P., Cummings, V., Guzzi, A., Hawes, I., Lohrer, A., Marini, S., ... & Kim, S. (2019). Underwater photogrammetry in Antarctica: long-term observations in benthic ecosystems and legacy data rescue. Polar Biology, 1-19.  All our protocols will be released through the SCAR-ANTOS (https://www.scar.org/science/antos/home/).  ARMS follow the standard procedures used everywhere (https://www.oceanarms.org)

prog_network: The U.S. Integrated Ocean Observing System (IOOS)
prog_funders: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
key_inst: https://aoos.org/aoos-governance/ provides information about our BOARD, https://aoos.org/stakeholders-2/  Scroll down to see a list of our primary stakeholders and Principal Participants
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_moreinfo: We provide funding for a network of data collectors and providers to conduct critical observing and we manage the data from all of our funded activities, as well as provide data management services to other programs operating in our region. AOOS maintains the largest data acquisition center for the state and region of Alaska, including the U.S. Arctic.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: We trial new technologies for remote observing installations https://aoos.org/new-aoos-projects-to-test-land-based-water-level-techniques/), and we participate in the IOOS OTT program to help new technologies progress to operational stages. We also support others to implement new observing instruments and technologies to fill data gaps, mostly in remote regions of Alaska where traditional technologies cannot be used.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: Most of our sampling locations funded by AOO are not real time.
duration_moreinfo: The stations of active sampling are provided in the spatial file/map information I just completed above. AOOS also has ingested numerous historical biological data sets, too numerous to provide here. You can contact Carol Janzen for more information on this.
freq_moreinfo: We have several moorings that sample at least hourly. Those are provided as boxes. The two moorings with biological parameters include the Gulf of Alaska Ecosystem mooring https://nga.lternet.edu/research/gulf-of-alaska-ecosystem-observatory-geo/) and the Chukchi Sea Ecosystem mooring (http://research.cfos.uaf.edu/ceo/). The transect lines sample usually quarterly, though the Gulf of Alaska line coming out of Seward is done 4 times a year between May and September.  The polygon shape in the Chukchi Sea is the area in which a marine mammal detection glider operates annually (since 2013). The other polygon shapes offshore of Utquiagvik (Barrow) and off the Bering Strait are HF Radar surface current areas (Essential Ocean Variables). I included wave buoys for sea state and surface temperature, located as moorings off of Nome, Kodiak and Lower Cook Inlet (near Homer). Transect lines near Homer are part of the Gulf Watch Program, and surveys occur quarterly. Happy to provide more information.
protocols_moreinfo: AOOS manages data, so we follow standard data management protocols, which includes collecting metadata from the data providers to our program. This requires them to provide us their SOPs. To learn more, visit this link, which provides our data management subsystem plan (Sept 2016). We also have data provider protocols, and I can send you those in a separate mailing if you would like.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: We provide quality controlled and processed data to the public. All data providers are required to provide us the final data (processed and corrected). We may have instances where we also have the original raw data. To have access to the RAW data (unaltered or converted or corrected), we defer to the data provider. I will need to investigate more if we make any raw data available on our website.  We always provide a link in the metadata to the original data provider.
dataaccess_WorkingToMakeOpenInFuture_Oth: Not sure if we are doing this. We provide ready to use data. Raw data to me means binary or sensor logs, not converted engineering units or biological units.
In_OBIS: I don't know if the biological data collected by the network is included in OBIS

If you want exact locations, I can send you an ASSET inventory that we provide for realtime obs only to IOOS annually. I tried to provide weblinks for each project above so you could see what variables are being collected. Let me know how I can further assist. Big undertaking. Thanks for your efforts! Carol with AOOS

prog_name: The Management Unit of the North Sea Mathematical Models - Offshore windfarms in Belgium
prog_funders: Scientific Service of the Operational Directorate Natural Environment (OD Nature) of the Royal Belgian Institute of Natural Sciences (RBINS)
key_inst: Research Institute for Nature and Forest (INBO), the Institute for Agricultural and Fisheries Research (ILVO)
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_moreinfo: OD Nature coordinates a monitoring program to estimate the positive and negative effects of the windmills at sea within the Belgian Part of the North sea and therefore collaborates with several institutions to cover all necessary scientific expertise.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: MUMM (follow-up activities at sea) covers a large area of research within the Belgian Part of The North Sea (BPNS). For the follow-up of environmental impacts of offshore windfarms in the BPNS this is mainly concentrated within the eastern zone (where the concession zones are situated). The Marine Biology department of the UGhent has been responsible for the monitoring of soft-sediment macrobenthos within two offshore windfarms (C-Power, Belwind) within the BPNS. Before installation, T0 baseline data was collected and since 2015, a yearly large-scale monitoring (macrobenthos sampling) is conducted within both windfarms and at reference sites.
duration_moreinfo: T0 (baseline-conditions) were sampled at both windfarms (C-Power built between 2008-2013 and Belwind 2009-2010). From 2015 onwards, large-scale monitoring is conducted within both wind farms by comparing "far" and "close" point from the turbines. In addition, reference samples are always taken at Goote Bank and since 2019 also at the western edge of Belwind.
protocols_moreinfo: systematic stratified sampling design: ‘Very close’ samples were taken at approximately 37.5 m from the center of the turbine, whereas far samples were collected in the middle between the four surrounding wind turbines (i.e., farthest possible distance), i.e., at distances between 350 and 500 m from any windmill.  The samples were collected from the vessels by means of a 0.1 m2 Van Veen grab. A plexiglass core (Ø 3.6 cm) was taken from each Van Veen grab sample to collect the environmental data which include: grain size distribution (reported: median grain size (MGS)), total organic matter content (TOM) and sediment fraction larger than 2 mm (> 2 mm).  The rest of the sample was sieved on board (1-mm mesh-sized sieve), and the macrofauna was preserved in a 4% formaldehyde-seawater solution and stained with Rose Bengal. In the laboratory, organisms were sorted, counted and identified to the lowest possible taxonomic level. Biomass was also determined for each taxon level as blotted wet weight (mg).

prog_name: TREE Foundation Sea Turtle Protection Force
prog_funders: Partial funding received from Andhra Pradesh Forest Department, Disney Conservation Fund and smaller individual and corporate donations
funder_moreinfo: Core activity funding comes directly from TREE Foundation, additional funding as above supplements activities.
key_inst: Indian Coast Guard, Marine Police, Forest Departments of Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh and Odisha.
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_moreinfo: TREE Foundation employs people from fishing communities - Sea Turtle Protection Force (STPF) along the east coast of India from Odisha in the north to Tamil Nadu in the south. STPF members are informed of strandings at a local level and attend to examine, identify, take measurements and photographs etc
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Due to budgetary constraints all observations are hands on and technology free. Photos are forwarded to TREE head office in Chennai to confirm species identification.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: Sporadic sites along the east coast of India
protocols_moreinfo: TREE Foundation has developed standardized data collection methods that are now used in all 3 states.

dataaccess_restriction_level: Restricted access- only data provider and another entity (e.g. contractor) have access to raw data

prog_name: United States Antarctic Marine Living Resources Program
prog_funders: National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration, U.S. National Marine Fisheries Service
funder_moreinfo: The Department of Commerce is mandated, via the U.S. Antarctic Marine Living Resources Convention Act of 1984, to conduct a program of directed research in support of U.S. objectives regarding the management of living marine resources in Antarctica and the Southern Ocean. The U.S. AMLR Program implements that mandate.
key_inst: U.S. Department of State, National Science Foundation
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
duration_moreinfo: The specific locations of sampling and the nature of sampling have changed over the years, but the polygon represented in response to a previous question covers the vast majority of sampling effort.
freq_moreinfo: Although sampling is nominally once per year (during the austral summer), sampling frequency within the summer ranges from sub-daily to monthly.
protocols_moreinfo: We use standard protocols for estimating the biomass of Antarctic krill and monitoring seabirds and pinnipeds. These protocols are largely defined by the Scientific Committee for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Reources.

prog_name: Virginia Coast Reserve Long-Term Ecological Research
prog_funders: National Science Foundation
key_inst: LTER Network, Boston University, George Washington University, Virginia Tech, Virginia Institute of Marine Sciences, Virginia Commonwealth University
type_moreinfo: We focus on the shallow lagoons, barrier islands and marshes along the Atlantic coast of Virginia
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: Sediment flux measurements in coastal systems
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
spatial_moreinfo: The sampling locations listed are the middle of the bounding boxes for the datasets. More precise locations are available, but there are a lot of them!  You can view a map of them at: https://www.vcrlter.virginia.edu/data/eml2/datamap.html
freq_moreinfo: We capture data at everything from 10 Hz, although most automated measurements are 1-10 times per hour.
protocols_moreinfo: We have developed protocols for our recurrent sampling of water quality, fish density, marsh elevation, end-of-year biomass etc.

prog_name: Water Framework Directive monitoring programme in coastal and transitional waters
prog_funders: Ministry of Environment & Energy
key_inst: Fisheries Research Institute (FRI) which belongs to the HELLENIC Agricultural Organization-DEMETER (ELGO–DEMETER)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_moreinfo: The WFD Monitoring Network is assessing the ecological status of coastal and transitional waters in Greece. The biological elements of Phytoplakton, Seaweeds, Seagrasses and Benthic Macroinvertebrates, the hyrdomorphological (currents and circulation), the geochemical (sediment granulometry and total organic carbon) and several physicochemical paramaters (water column temparature, salinity, turbidity, dissolved oxygen, nutrients and heavy metals) are monitored in 114 sampling stations.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: The WFD monitoring network is also part of the MSFD monitoring network

prog_funders: Wildlife Conservation Society, Department of Science and Technology, Government of India
funder_moreinfo: Funding for the long-term monitoring of the Andaman islands has been based on project basis.
key_inst: Dr, Rohan Arthur, Nature Conservation Foundation
type_NetworkRawData: Network of raw data collectors/providers (network/program coordinates many individual entities that collect data)
type_DataAggregator: Data aggregator (network/program stores or combines data, but the raw data is collected elsewhere)
type_ProductDeveloper: Data product developer (network/program takes raw data and creates data products)
type_DataUser: Data user (network/program uses the data from observing networks)
type_Directory: Directory of programs/networks/observatories (the program provides information on observing networks/programs)
type_moreinfo: In the Andaman Islands, we are (1) documenting patterns and processes of reef ecosystem (2) describing on-going shifts on reef ecosystems caused due to the impact of humans and climate change.    We have 10 permanent sites that we monitor every year. WE collect data on hard coral cover percent cover, benthic communities, reef fish communities.     In addition, we have been using Soundtrap 300 instrument, and collecting soundscape level data and working towards establishing a long-term passive acoustic monitoring program in the Andaman Islands.
CapacityDevTechTransfer_moreinfo: We do not have funds for conducting capacity building programs, but I am interested in advancing my skillsets, in sharing my findings, and communicating with other observatory or reef monitoring programs.
spatial_options: Option 2: Provide a spatial csv file in the format described above and send it to satterthwaite@nceas.ucsb.edu (recommended for sampling programs with more than 10 sites)
protocols_moreinfo: We follow standard protocols that are being used by GCRMN, Nature Conservancy, WCS, and other similar programs.
dataaccess_AnyRawBioDataRestrictions: Yes, there are restrictions to raw data access.
dataaccess_restriction_level: Access by request only- anyone can get access but need to formally ask
dataaccess_moreinfo: There is a lot of raw data, but due to my limitation in analysis, organizing and cleaning vast dataset, I am unable to make my data open access (though I would like to)

prog_name: West Coast Vancouver Island Sea Otter Community Ecology Project
prog_funders: Presently mostly self funded
funder_moreinfo: This is a long term project that stems from PhD research conducted in the 1980s. I have maintained the project - there is actually little funding for monitoring work in British Columbia - so the project was designed to be small and self sustainable in years where there is no money.    The Department of Fisheries and Oceans supports the work in principle (colleagues there) as does Vancouver Island University, the Vancouver Aquarium  and the Hakai Institute. All have provided support of one type or another over the years.
key_inst: Department of Fisheries and Oceans Canada (sea otter portion), Vancouver Island University, Vancouver Aquarium, Hakai Institute
type_moreinfo: There are a series of permanently marked subtidal sites that are monitored annually. We conduct sea otter surveys annually in the same area. There are 60 originally randomly chosen sites that are monitored on approximately 7 year intervals. All work (except the otter counts) is conducted subtidally.
spatial_options: Option 1: Use the point/polygon tool provided on the next page of the survey to draw your sampling sites/locations (recommended for sampling programs without a csv file or programs with less than 10 sites)
